courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Field Studies in Hong Kong
courses.description: Field studies is an integral part in the study of geography, which gives students an opportunity to understand real-world situations and to supplement the lectures. This is an introductory field studies course conducted locally by faculty members in Winter for students majoring in geography and resource management. The objectives are three-fold: (1) to introduce students to different techniques in the collection of field data; (2) to help students identify, understand and explain the geographical problems of a region; and (3) to provide an opportunity for students to work as a team in problem-solving. Students are required to participate in all activities throughout the field camp and to submit an individual report afterwards.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students will be able to:

• understand on-site data collection skills and field techniques;
• interpret geographical issues from urban and rural settings; and

• enhance group-work ability and team spirit.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course evaluation

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Understanding China through Cultural Landscape
courses.description:
(UGEA1212 is double-coded with GRMD1003.)

This course aims to introduce China’s cultural heritages from the perspective of cultural geography. As an important sub-discipline in human geography, cultural geography examines how people use space and develop it into places – a process of cultural landscape formation. “Space” here is nothing immutable or monolithic; instead, individuals, groups, civilizations and their culture “craft” characteristic places through interactions with the surrounding environment and specific political and economic systems (themselves determined by culture). China provides numerous extraordinary examples to illustrate these topics. The course includes four key components: 1) the theoretical foundation: fundamentals of cultural geography; 2) the legacies and regional variations of China’s cultural heritages; 3) topical issues about China’s cultural heritages; 4) the cultural convergence in aspects of globalization and cultural transformation. The course provides not only a body of knowledge about the cultural landscape and spatial variations of places in China, but also an understanding of their major transformations that have taken place in a globalizing world.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
GRMD1003 is double-coded with UGEA1212.
Not for students who have taken UGEA1212 or GESC2380.
courses.learning_outcomes:
| Students are expected to develop a general and comprehensive understanding of China’s cultural heritages, using the approach of cultural geography. Broad issues regarding China’s cultural heritages will be discussed to appreciate that cultural landscape formation is the result of multiple forces (e.g. natural, geographical, social, economic, political, etc) working together to form space and then places. After completing the course, students will be able to: * adopt a normative stance in evaluating the cultural landscapes; * identify essential features of China’s cultural heritages from the lens of cultural geography; * understand Chinese cultural heritages’ multiple dimensions and geographical variations, and how these factors shape and reinforce space, place and cultural formation; * discover cases or use experiences to describe and diagnose how the development of Chinese cultural heritages is associated with forces at different geographical scales such as local, regional, national and even global scales; * organize their ideas and information under the framework of cultural geography; and * explain their ideas in a communicative manner to promote Chinese culture. |
| --- |
courses.course_syllabus:
As shown below, the course contents will be divided into 4 parts and 12 topics.

Part I: Fundamental of Cultural Geography: Interpreting Places and Spaces of Cultural Heritages (3 lectures):

This component covers key theories and concepts developed over the past 30 years in cultural geography (both classical and new cultural geography approaches), and explain why cultural geography offers a very unique but important approach to study China’s cultural heritages. Theoretical exploration will help bring out ideas about space, place, power, cultural landscape, and identity. How people use space and develop it into place will be discussed. Many examples will be used to help students understand the approaches of cultural geography.

1. Introduction: cultural geography as an approach

文化地理方法导读

2. Culture, space, place and power

文化、空間、地方與權力

3. Shaping of China’s cultural landscape: traditions, foreign imports, and globalization

中国文化景觀的形成：傳統、外來影響與全球化

Part II: Cultural Heritages and Regional Variations (5 lectures)

In the first three weeks, the course has laid the theoretical foundation. Now, student will begin their journey of understanding the subject matter, with a focus on several key cultural regions in China. The aim of this component is to covey a deep sense of place as an integral system engaging multiple force, e.g. myth and legend, power and politics, history and tradition, religion and symbol, nature and geography, cultural practices, and society’s interconnection with the environment. Students will make a good sense of a wide geographical variation of Chinese cultural values and practices.

4. Beijing: Beijing Culture and the place of politics

北京：京派文化與空間的政治

5. Shanghai: Shanghai Culture and the place for spatial competition

上海：海派文化與空間的爭奪

6. Southwest: Ethnic culture and the place of ethnicity

西南：民族文化與鄉土空間

7. Tibet: Religious culture and the place of belief

西藏：宗教文化與信仰空間

8. Lingnan: Lingnan culture and the place of diversity

嶺南：嶺南文化與多元空間

Part III: China’s Cultural Imprints and Dynamics: Topical Issues (3 lectures)

The aim of this component is to let students further appreciate the diversified studies of cultural geography by introducing several topical issues.

9. Ancient villages: A place of spatial representation

古村落的空間意象

10. The cultures of production and workspace

生産的文化與勞動場所

11. Graffiti: the cultural geography of Youth in China

塗鴉：青年文化地理

Part IV: Cultural Convergence and Transformation (Globalization) (1 lecture)

Globalization is an unescapable trend, and this powerful trend has greatly impacted on China’s cultural heritages. The cultural convergence and transformation will be discussed. The focus is not simply to interpret convergence as some kind of loss of unique characteristics of our cultural tradition. Rather, we wish to stress that when one gets involved in intercultural interaction, one should be likely to become aware of and even enhance one’s cultural tradition. Problems and local responses in cultural heritage conservation in China will be explored.

12. China’s cultural heritage under globalization: a cultural geography perspective

全球化下的中国文化遺產: 文化地理學的解讀

It is an introductory field studies course conducted locally by faculty members in Winter for students majoring in geography and resource management. The objectives are three-fold: (1) to introduce students to different techniques in the collection of field data; (2) to help students identify, understand and explain the geographical problems of a region; and (3) to provide an opportunity for students to work as a team in problem-solving. Students are required to participate in all learning activities throughout the field camp and to submit an individual report afterwards.

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Understanding Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area

meetings.instructor:
Dr. GUO Chunlan, 
Professor LEE Wai Ying Joanna

Dr. GUO Chunlan, 
Professor LEE Wai Ying Joanna

courses.description:
(UGEC1120 is double-coded with GRMD1301.)

Since the establishment of the Special Administrative Region in 1997 under “One Country Two Systems”, the synergy between Hong Kong, Macao and the PRD has been renewed. With the recent Central Government's initiative of the development of Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area, there will be closer and mutually beneficial co-operation among cities in this economic region. This will reshape the socio-economic relations and the urban landscapes of the three places. Studying the changing relations of Hong Kong, Macao and the PRD will not only help students understand the dynamic socio-economic development of the Greater Bay Area as a rapidly growing mega-city region in the world, but also capture the latest transformation of the region. A wide variety of teaching and learning activities, including lectures, forums and video watching will be conducted to present a lively and comprehensive picture of the Greater Bay Area to students.
courses.course_syllabus:
Lecture topics:

Getting to know Hong Kong and the Pearl River Delta

• Hong Kong, Macao and the PRD: The geographical setting and changing spatial relationship (香港、澳門與珠江三角洲:地理位置與空間關係轉變)

• From farming to manufacturing: socio-economic transformation of the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area (從桑基魚塘到世界工廠：粵港澳大灣區經濟社會變遷)

Economic aspect

• Foreign direct investment: angel or devil? (外來投資：天使或魔鬼？)

• CEPA and Greater Bay Area (CEPA 與粵港澳大灣區)

• Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area: a premier tourist destination (粵港澳大灣區:旅遊業新景象)

Social and environmental aspects

• Cross-border infrastructure development in the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area: competition vs cooperation (粵港澳大灣區跨境基建：全面規劃還是各施各法？)

• Migration in the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area (粵港澳大灣區人口流動)

• From state to market: how to satisfy the housing demand in the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area (從國家分配到市場機制：如何滿足粵港澳大灣區人口的住房需求?)

• Environmental degradation – a necessary evil of economic growth? (環境惡化–經濟增長之必然代價？)

Governance and planning

• Planning sustainable cities and region in the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area (粵港澳大灣區城市與區域可持續發展規劃)

• One country, many systems: competition or cooperation in the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area ‘一囯多制’：競爭還是合作？

• Mega-city regions: the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area from global perspective (全球視野中的粵港澳大灣區城市群發展)

Two video watching and discussion sessions

• 商機無限

• 走進大灣區。機

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: People, Space and Place
courses.description: Geography matters now more than ever because we are living in a globalized world. This course introduces students about the human geographic matters pertinent to cultural development and socio-economic and political changes. Important subjects to be discussed include the geographic dynamics of human culture, urban development, people’s livelihood, geopolitics and new world order, and economic restructuring across the globe. Emphasis will be placed on the nexus between economic globalization and local development as well as regional disparity in our global village.
courses.course_syllabus:
Part I: Culture and Development

1 Culture, languages, and religions

2 Development: patterns and change

Part II: Urban Systems and Urban Structures

3 Urbanization and urban change

4 Land use in the city

5 Urban planning and policy

6 Third World urbanization

7 Internal structure of Third World cities

Part III: People’s livelihood

8 Residential differentiation and urban liveability

9 Housing and environmental problems

10 Urban transportation

Part IV: Politics and economy

11 The political ordering of space

12 The economy of cities

13 National and local responses to urban economic change
courses.feedback_evaluation:
• Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey

• Internal Course Review

• Informal discussion with students

• Pacione, M. (2009), Urban Geography: A Global Perspective, 3rd Edition. London and New York, Routledge.

courses.description: This course looks at the interplay between the natural and human aspects of the world’s regions. Planet Earth is a complex system with diverse climatic zones, landforms, geology, soils, vegetation and habitats; the processes and forces leading to their evolution and formation are different in both spatial and temporal scales. The course examines these complexities of nature and discusses the ways in which different societies have dealt with it. Over the history of human civilizations, different societies have taken very different approaches towards nature. This is reflected in different aspects of social institutions (political, economic, social, cultural, religious, etc.) that human beings have created to organize themselves.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken GRMD1404.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking the course, students should be able to:

(1) Understand diversities of the world in terms of physical geography (e.g., climatic zones, landforms, geology, soils and ecosystems), regional geography (national, regional and global scales) and human geography (races and populations, economic and political systems, culture, religion, food and agriculture, and energy usage)

(2) Understand the complex structure of the earth system and how human societies are formed from the geographical, economic, social and political perspectives.

(3) Analyse the effect of human activities on the environment and vice versa.

(4) Develop critical thinking on the relationship between globalization and sustainable development for a world of differences.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week Lecture Topic

1. Introduction: The global physical environment

2. Asia: A continent full of environmental challenges

3. Australia, Oceania, and Antarctica: The impacts of global environmental change

4. Russia: The frigid north

5. Europe and Africa: The dead zones

6. North and Latin America: The power of humans

7. Introduction: The Geography of Human Environment

8. India: Urban informality as a way of life

9. Asia: “Pacific Century”?

10. Europe and Africa: European hegemony and colonialism

11. North and Latin America: Overseas Chinese in America

12. Global North and Global South: Closing the gap?

13. Conclusion
courses.feedback_evaluation: Early course evaluation; course evaluation; e-discussion forum; feedback sheets on essays and presentations; feedback on examination; verbal feedback

courses.description: This course introduces a geographical approach to the study of global environmental change and its threats to environmental sustainability. Emphasizing the interconnections between human and physical systems, this course examines the significance of environmental sustainability to the survival of human society, the contemporary forms and causes of global environmental change, and the opportunities and challenges to address global environmental change.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken GRMD1023.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After successfully completing this course, students will be able to:

1. Recognize key principles of environmental sustainability
2. Identify global change in key ecosystem components and processes
3. Analyze the roles of human activities in global environmental change
4. Evaluate human efforts to address global environmental change and restore environmental sustainability
courses.course_syllabus:
| | **Topic** | **Concepts** |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Drivers of environmental change and pressures on sustainability | | |
| 1 | Overview: Global changes, environmental problems and sustainability | DPSIR model; principles of sustainability |
| 2 | Changing environmental philosophy and modern environmentalism | Ego-centric vs. eco-centric; tragedy of the commons |
| 3 | Climate change: Trends and issues | COPs; greenhouse effect |
| Environmental change: Trends and consequences | | |
| 4 | Air quality | Environmental Kuznets curve; co-benefits |
| 5 | Energy | Resource vs. reserve; net energy |
| 6 | Water resources | Water security; virtual water |
| 7 | Tourism and its sustainability | Overtourism; principles of sustainable tourism |
| 8 | Food production | Productivism; water-food-energy nexus |
| Human responses to environmental change | | |
| 9 | Climate change and sustainable development | Climate justice; climate adaptation and mitigation; Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) |
| 10 | Environmental planning and assessment | Precautionary principle; forecasting vs. backcasting |
courses.feedback_evaluation: In addition to the course evaluation both during and at the end of the course, students are welcomed to provide feedback to the course instructors and/or the tutors through email. You are welcomed to meet any of the instructors by appointment.

courses.description: This course aims to introduce students to geography as a multi-faceted discipline with diverse fields, as well as its relationships with and contributions to the studies of resource management, social and environmental issues. It begins with a general introduction to geography and its sub-fields, and is divided into four areas of concentration which constitute our undergraduate curriculum in geography and resource management. An issue-based approach is adopted to address a wide range of selected topics with important local, regional, national and global significance from geographical perspectives. After taking the course, students will not only gain basic understanding of geographical concepts, principles and applications, but also become familiar with our curriculum and learning resources in their undergraduate study. All major students are required to take this introductory course and assigned to our teaching staff for academic advising.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Geography: Concepts, traditions and modern applications
2. Concentration 1: Physical and Environmental Systems
- Physical geography and the Earth system
- Climate change: The science, impacts and solutions
- Water security for sustainable development: Hong Kong, China and the world
3. Concentration 2: Urban and Regional Development
- World patterns and regional trends of population
- Sustainable urban development
- Globalization and local context
4. Concentration 3: Geographical Information and Analysis
- GIS: A tool for geographical study
- Remote sensing: Learning geography from images
5. Concentration 4: Global Change and Resource Management
- Energy resources
- Global climate governance
6. Field trip: Learning geography, environment and resource management on campus
7. Forum on jobs and career development of GRM graduates

courses.description: Field studies is an integral part in the study of geography. The benefits of field studies are enhanced by a study trip to a destination outside of Hong Kong. The course is held during term breaks under the supervision of one or more faculty members. The objectives are three-fold: (1) to broaden students’ horizon and knowledge base through exposure to a different and less familiar environment outside Hong Kong; (2) to enable students to make comparative studies across different countries or regions; and (3) to provide an opportunity for students to interact with non-local students and scholars in the same discipline. Students are required to participate in all activities throughout the trip and to submit an individual report afterwards.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: GRMD1001.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course Evaluation

meetings.instructor:

Dr. WONG Kwan Kit,

courses.description: Field studies are an integral part of the study of geography and resource management. The benefits of field studies are enhanced by a study trip to a destination outside of Hong Kong. The objectives are three-fold: (1) to broaden students’ horizons and knowledge base through exposure to a different and less familiar environment outside Hong Kong; (2) to enable students to make comparative studies across different countries or regions; and (3) to provide an opportunity for students to interact with non-local scholars and students in the same discipline. This field trip course is held during term breaks under the supervision of one or more faculty members. The theme of the field trip can be one or more Concentration Area(s) under the programme curriculum. Students are required to participate in all activities throughout the course and submit individual and/or group-based assignments.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: GRMD1011
courses.course_syllabus:
Part 1: Overview of field studies

* Overall briefing on non-local field studies (all the trips yearly) and registration

Part 2: Pre-trip preparations and orientation

* Introduction to the field trip destination and themes
* Briefing on the field trip requirements and logistics
* Pre-trip student presentations or other preparation work

Part 3: Field trip

* Visits and activities at the destination
* Visits and activities at the partner university(ies) or organisation(s)
* Fieldwork and learning activities related to the thematic Concentration Area(s) led by the trip leader(s)
* Data collection and research under the guidance of the trip leader(s)

Part 4: Post-trip reflection and assignments

* Post-trip student presentations and reflection on field trip experiences
* Submission of individual and/or group-based assignments
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course Evaluation
courses.required_readings: Required readings will be provided by respective trip leaders according to the theme and requirements of each trip.
courses.recommended_readings: Recommended readings will be provided by respective trip leaders according to the theme and requirements of each trip.

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Fundamental Statistics for Geographers

meetings.location: Chung Chi College Lib CK TSE

courses.description: This course emphasizes fundamental concepts of statistical methods which are applicable to geographic analysis. Topics include elementary probability and statistical theory, hypothesis testing, correlation analysis and regression analysis.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for student who have taken STAT1011, 1012 and 2101.
courses.learning_outcomes: After taking this course, students are expected to be able to (a) understand the basic concepts in simple statistics that are useful to geographical data analysis, (b) set up the framework for hypothesis testing with respect to the population mean and difference of population means, (c) employ probability distributions, particularly the normal distribution to describe data and test hypotheses, (d) test simple geographical relationships through the concepts of simple correlation and simple regression.
courses.course_syllabus:
I. General Background

Developments of Quantitative Analysis in Geography

Ideas of Probability and Statistics

Applications of Probability and Statistics in Geographical Research

II. Geographic Data and Description

Geographic Data

Describing Geographic Data

III. Probability Distribution

Probability Density Function and Mass Function

Normal Probability Law

IV. Concepts of Sampling

V. Descriptive and Inferential Statistics

Sample mean

Sample variance

VI. Testing of Hypotheses

Probability Arguments of Hypothesis Testing

Significance Test of Model Parameters and Linear Hypothesis

VII. Simple Correlation

Concepts and Estimations of Simple Correlation

| Qualitative feedback from students | Tutors and/or teacher through informal interaction | During lecture and outside class | Throughout the term |
| Course evaluation | Teacher and department | Lecture room | End of the term |
| Visiting examiner report | University, department and teacher | Overseas | End of the term |
| Reflection of teacher (including evidence from assessment) | Teacher and tutors | All learning activities | Throughout the term |
| Curriculum review | Related teachers and Curriculum & Teaching Committee | Department | End of the term |

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Remote Sensing of Environment
courses.description: This course discusses the principles of remote sensing and basic techniques of manual (visual) image interpretation. The use of aerial photographs and satellite images as data for acquiring geographic information and its implications for geographic research are introduced.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students should be able to
• understand the principles of remote sensing and visual interpretation techniques
• understand the nature of various remotely sensed images
• interpret various remotely sensed images with visual interpretation techniques
• understand the basic applications of remote sensing imagery
courses.course_syllabus:
Overview of the course
Principle of Remote Sensing
• Electromagnetic Radiation
• Electromagnetic Spectrum
• Spectral Bands
Energy Interactions in the Atmosphere
• Scattering and Absorption
• Atmospheric Windows
Energy Interactions at Terrestrial Surface
• Reflection, Absorption and Transmission
Spectral Properties of Terrestrial Features
(Image Interpretation)
Types of airphotos
• Black and white panchromatic
• Color
Types of airphotos
• Black and white infrared
• Color infrared
Geometry of airphotos
• Photo coordinate system
• Scale of photos
• Distance measurement
• Relief displacement
Photogrammetry
• Parallax
• Orthophotos
Satellite Images and interpretation
• Types of satellites
• Landsat TM
• SPOT
• IKONOS
• Quickbird
Thermal IR images and interpretation
• Sensing Thermal Temperature
• Thermal Properties of Objects
• Geometry of Thermal Images
• TIR images from Space
Radar images and interpretation
• Principles of radar
• SLAR
• Resolution and Geometry
• Polarization, Look angle and Look direction
• Radar images from Space
Land use and land cover mapping
• Nature of land use and land cover
• Land use and land cover classification system
• Mapping procedures
Urban and industrial analysis
• Image requirements for urban analysis
• Urban socioeconomic patterns
• Housing quality
• Population estimation
• Industrial classifications
Vegetation studies
• Vegetation index
• Crop type and area mapping
• Monitoring of crop growth
• Crop yield estimation
• Forest management
courses.feedback_evaluation: Early course evaluation, classroom discussion, discussion and mail with webCT, course evaluation

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Introduction to GIS
courses.description: This course introduces to students the basic principles and applications of Geographical Information Systems (GIS). The emphasis is on the use of GIS to organize, manage and analyze spatial data. Topics include hardware/software components, vector and raster data models, data management, spatial analysis, and application issues. Students will develop their competency in using and applying GIS tools through hands-on lab exercises and a course project.
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the end of this course, students are expected to:

- Understand the principles of spatial data models, spatial database, and spatial analysis,
- Develop proficiency in using GIS functions relevant to the aforementioned components, and
- Apply the knowledge to solve geographical problems using GIS
courses.course_syllabus:
Week Topic
1 Introduction to GIS
2 GIS Data Input
3 GIS Data Editing
4 Spatial Data Model (I)
Holiday
5 Spatial Data Model (II)
6 Attribute Data Management
7 Spatial Analysis (I)
8 Spatial Analysis (II)
9 Spatial Analysis (III)
10 Designing and Managing GIS
11 Project discussions
12 GIS applications
13 GIS applications
courses.feedback_evaluation: Early course evaluatio; course evaluation

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Introduction to Satellite Design and Application
courses.description: The distance between space technologies and human society has been reduced since the launch of the first artificial satellite in the 1950s. As satellite-related technologies and applications become ubiquitous in our lives, it becomes prominent to be equipped with the fundamental knowledge in the field of satellite and aerospace science. In this course, the brief history of satellite development, basic components and design procedures will be introduced, followed by a discussion of the applications of satellites, with a focus on Earth observation satellites, as well as the rapidly advancing small satellites and satellite constellations, with the objective to lay critical foundations for students interested in pursuing advanced studies in the field of aerospace science and Earth informatics.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1 Introduction to Satellites

* Definition and classification of satellites: e.g., communication, weather, etc.
* History and evolution of satellite and related technology

Week 2 Satellite Subsystems

* Power systems: solar panels and batteries
* Communication systems: transponders and antennas
* Thermal control systems and their importance
* Attitude control systems: sensors, actuators and importance of proper attitude control

Week 3 Satellite development processes; launch vehicles and deployment; ground segment

* Requirements analysis and basics of system engineering principles
* Trade studies and design optimization

* Assembly processes and testing methods (e.g. vibration, thermal vacuum, electromagnetic interference)

* Types of launch vehicles; launch process and trajectory
* Deployment mechanisms; propulsion systems of satellites
* Ground stations and control centers; Data processing and analysis

* Communication links with satellites

Week 4 Fundamentals of remote sensing

* Electromagnetic radiation and spectrum
* Concepts of resolutions: spectral resolution; radiometric resolution
* Scattering, reflection, absorption and transmission; atmospheric window

Week 5 Introduction of CUHK Satellite

* Specification: e.g. spectral bands; orbit and altitude; swath width
* Concepts of resolutions: spatial resolution; temporal resolution
* Applications and proposed efficacy

Week 6 Introduction of SDGSAT

* Specification: e.g. spectral bands; orbit and altitude; swath width
* Applications: e.g. nighttime light monitoring for energy evaluation [SDG 7]; urban expansion [SDG 11]

Week 7 Earth observation and remote sensing (I)

* Band combinations
* Optical and hyperspectral imagery
* Applications: e.g. (optical) GHG monitoring satellites [SDG 13]; plant diversity [SDG 15]

Week 8 Earth observation and remote sensing (II)

* Microwave and radar remote sensing
* Active sensing vs passive sensing; common bandwidth used
* Applications: e.g. (passive sensing) ice coverage [SDG 13]; soil moisture [SDG 15]; (active sensing) altimetry and change detection (e.g. land subsidence; post-earthquake assessment) [SDG 11]

Week 9 Reading week (no class)

Week 10 Earth observation and remote sensing (III)

* Combinations of different imagery and/or remote sensing techniques: e.g. optical imagery with InSAR; hyperspectral imagery with microwave remote sensing
* Fundamentals of supervised and unsupervised classification, and other imagery processing techniques
* Applications: e.g. urban surface mapping [SDG 11]; habitat quality evaluation and invasive species detection [SDG 15]; water quality monitoring [SDG 6/ SDG 14]

Week 11 Future trends in satellite technology; satellite constellations and applications

* Miniaturization and CubeSats
* Advances in propulsion and artificial intelligence (e.g. onboard pre-processing)

“Construction” of satellite constellations

* Possible examples: Beidou system; GEO AQ satellite constellation
* Applications: IoT and health monitoring [SDG 3]; disaster response [SDG 11]; air pollution monitoring [SDG 3]

Week 12 Q and A session (3-hour session)

Week 13 Presentation (3-hour session)
courses.feedback_evaluation: An early course evaluation survey will be conducted in Week 6 and a final one will be conducted towards the end of the semester.

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Field Trip in Geographical Science
courses.description: Field studies are an integral part of the study of geography and resource management. The benefits of field studies are enhanced by a study trip to a destination outside of Hong Kong. The objectives are three-fold: (1) to broaden students’ horizons and knowledge base through exposure to a different and less familiar environment outside Hong Kong; (2) to enable students to make comparative studies across different countries or regions; and (3) to provide an opportunity for students to interact with non-local scholars and students in the same discipline. This field trip course is held during term breaks under the supervision of one or more faculty members or invited trip leaders. The theme of the field trip can be relevant to the Concentration Area(s) under geography and resource management. Students are required to participate in all activities throughout the course and submit individual and/or group-based assignments.
courses.course_syllabus:
Part 1: Overview of field studies

* Overall briefing on non-local field studies (all the trips yearly) and registration

Part 2: Pre-trip preparations and orientation

* Introduction to the field trip destination and themes
* Briefing on the field trip requirements and logistics
* Pre-trip student presentations or other preparation work

Part 3: Field trip

* Visits and activities at the destination
* Visits and activities at the partner university(ies) or organisation(s)
* Fieldwork and learning activities related to the thematic Concentration Area(s) led by the trip leader(s)
* Data collection and research under the guidance of the trip leader(s)

Part 4: Post-trip reflection and assignments

* Post-trip student presentations and reflection on field trip experiences
* Submission of individual and/or group-based assignments
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course Evaluation
courses.required_readings: Required readings will be provided by respective trip leaders according to the theme and requirements of each trip.
courses.recommended_readings: Recommended readings will be provided by respective trip leaders according to the theme and requirements of each trip.

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Physical Geology
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to the physical domain of the planet Earth. Topics include the materials (i.e., minerals and rocks) of which the earth is made, the geological processes that act on these materials, the structures (e.g., faults, folds) and products (e.g., landforms and natural hazards) created, the geological time and natural history, and the environmental change and evolution of the planet. Along with the course lectures which introduce students to key information and concepts of the discipline, field trips and exercise stressing the application of geological techniques are held periodically to reinforce specific theories and concepts.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completion of this course, students should:

• understand the geological processes controlling the evolution of the Earth;
• know the structures and formations of various landforms over the world; and

• develop field skills for geological survey

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Weather and Climate
courses.description: This is a physical geography course about the atmosphere, weather and climate. The course provides students with knowledge of the atmosphere, atmospheric processes as the driving forces of weather and climate, weather systems and finally world climates and their classification. Illustration of weather elements and the related fundamental physical principles, as well as their applications in studying weather and climate, will be emphasized. Major concepts and principles of meteorology and climatology constitute the core of this course. Weather systems and climate will be examined from a global perspective, yet with a regional focus on Hong Kong, mainland China and East Asia.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Through a variety of teaching and learning activities, students will be expected to achieve the outcomes of understanding the concepts, basic principles, and applications on the following topics in the studies of weather and climate.

1. the composition and vertical structure of the atmosphere, and a general knowledge of atmospheric sciences as studies of weather and climate
2. energy and heat, solar and terrestrial radiation, and air temperature
3. atmospheric moisture and humidity, atmospheric stability and formation of clouds, and the processes, causes, types of precipitation
4. atmospheric pressure and forces controlling winds, winds of different types and atmospheric circulation
5. air masses and fronts, weather tracking and forecasting, and major hazardous weather systems
6. climate controls and distribution, classification of world climates
courses.course_syllabus:
COURSE CONTENTS

Required readings

Part I Introduction to the Atmosphere A1(1-23) or A2(1-23)

Composition of the atmosphere

Structure of the atmosphere

Elements of weather and climate

Scientific disciplines and practical applications

# Part II Atmospheric Processes

# Radiation, energy balance and air temperature A1(25-77) or A2(25-80)

Radiation of sun and earth

Atmospheric effects on solar radiation

Energy balance of the earth-atmosphere system

Atmospheric temperature and seasonal variations

Atmospheric moisture, clouds and precipitation

Humidity and dew point A1(79-91) or A2(105-124)

Atmospheric stability and cloud development A1(97-125) or A2(136-179)

Processes, types, and measurement of precipitation A1(126-138) or A2(181-207)

Air pressure and winds

Atmospheric pressure, measurement, and isobaric maps A1(141-148) or A2(208-221)

Forces controlling winds A1(149-156) or A2(221-224)

Upper air and surface winds A1(156-166) or A2(225-237)

Local wind systems A1(169-179) or A2(253-266)

# Planetary-scale motions in the A1(184-201) or A2(273-299)

# atmosphere and ocean

Idealized circulation pattern

Pressure systems and wind belts

Jet streams

Atmosphere-ocean interactions

Part III Weather Systems

Air masses and fronts A1(203-220) or A2(301-324)

Air masses: source regions and classification

Air masses of East Asia

Fronts: classification and weather conditions

Weather tracking and forecasting dMW(184-199)

Weather data acquisition A1(235-253) or A2(351-379)

Mapping weather data

Weather forecasting

Hazardous weather systems

Thunderstorms and tornadoes A1(263-297) or A2(381-417)

Hurricanes (Typhoons) A1(299-325) or A2(419-439)

ZL(17-30)

Part IV Climate

Global climate A1(353-380) or A2(471-503)

An overview of world climates dMW(200-249)

A summary of climate controls

Climatic classification – The Köppen system

The regional distribution of climate types

A1: Ahrens (2008) A2: Ahrens (2003)

dMW: deBlij, Muller and Williams (2004) ZL: Zhang and Lin (1992)

READING ASSIGNMENTS

There are four reference books as listed below. Students are required to purchase the first text book by Donald Ahrens at the Academic & Professional Book Centre (G05, Li Wai Chun Building, Tel: 2398 3044). The other three books are reserved at the University Library. Students are required to read the sections/chapters of the reference books that are shown on the right side of the Course Contents.

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Understanding Ecotourism
courses.description:
(UGEC2192 is double-coded with GRMD2292.)
The first part of the course will cover the general introductory concepts and provide students with theoretical and historical background of the discipline. This will be followed by in-depth study of specific environmental settings and resource issues that will complement our understanding of ecotourism. Hong Kong is the main focus of discussion though examples or cases in Mainland China and around the world are also provided throughout the course. Critical issues in ecotourism such as its multi-dimensional impacts, governance, planning, and resource and visitor management will also be covered. Lastly, students will be exposed to the relation of the phenomenon of ecotourism and the concept of sustainable tourism. Some of the lectures will address SDGs, for example, Goals 12, 16 and 17 embrace the knowledge and evolution of environmentalism and nature-human relationship; Goals 14 and 15 connect with the concept of protected areas and environmental conservation; Goals 1, 3, 5, 8, 11, 12 and 13 cover multi-dimensional tourism impacts and, more importantly, climate change issue. The concept of sustainable development will frame and conclude the entire course since the concepts has played an indispensable role in tourism development nowadays.
courses.course_attributes:
SDG-GE #12 Responsible Consumption and Production
SDG-GE #14 Life Below Water
SDG-GE #15 Life On Land
Experiential Learning Course
courses.learning_outcomes:
| This course will provide a broad intellectual perspective for students and enable them to develop a holistic understanding of environmental and resource management issues related to ecotourism. Students will acquire basic knowledge of ecotourism development and its potential and can be capable of making judgment in response to critical issues on conservation and natural resource management. Since ecotourism, sustainable tourism and sustainable development (including SDGs) are inter-connected concepts in theoretical and practical perspectives, students are expected to incorporate and integrate these areas of knowledge with various cases and examples provided in the course. Specifically, after successfully completing this course, students will be able to: - Understand the basic concepts of ecotourism and its relation with the overall tourism industry; especially connecting ecotourism with sustainable tourism development; - Acquire knowledge in operating and managing ecotourism activities; and particularly how these ecotourism activities may impact economic, socio-cultural and ecological/environmental sustainability; - Develop an understanding and the skills and approaches necessary for interpreting relevant policy and planning of natural and man-made resources for (eco)tourism; and - Enhance problem-solving capability using an integrative approach and critical thinking as introduced in the course, which draws students’ attention to how tourism and ecotourism may contribute to SDGs potentially |
| --- |
courses.course_syllabus:
| This course includes the following main topics of teaching: 1) Ecotourism: An introduction (What is tourism, ecotourism and sustainable development?) *(SDG 12)* 2) The ideology of ecotourism and environmental conservation (How does ecotourism connect with environmentalism and sustainability?) *(SDGs 16, 17)* 3) Who are the ecotourists? (What is an ecotourist? Does the ecotourism market sustainable?) *(SDG 12)* 4) Ecotourism environments (What and where may ecotourism take place? How to protect these resources for ecotourism and sustainable tourism development?) *(SDGs 14, 15)* 5) Ecotourism in Hong Kong: Potential and limitations (What is status of ecotourism development in Hong Kong?) *(SDGs 8, 11, 14, 15)* 6) Geological landscape in Hong Kong as tourism resources (What is the Hong Kong UNESCO Global Geopark? How does the Geopark provide opportunity for ecotourism in Hong Kong?) *(SDGs 11, 14, 15)* 7) Ecotourism in Mainland China: Potential and limitations (What is status of ecotourism development in mainland China?) *(SDGs 1, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12)* 8) Impacts of ecotourism (What are the multi-dimensional impacts of tourism and ecotourism? How do these impacts affect the sustainability of ecotourism destinations?) *(SDGs 1, 3, 5, 8, 11, 12)* 9) Ecotourism planning and management (How can we plan and manage ecotourism effectively to achieve sustainable tourism development?) *(SDGs 1, 5, 8, 9, 10, 11, 16, 17)* 10) Conclusion: Ecotourism and sustainable tourism (How does climate change affect ecotourism and sustainable tourism development? What would be the possible future of tourism?) *(SDGs 1, 3, 5, 8, 11, 12, 13)* |
| --- |

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Urban Geography
courses.description: This course provides a comprehensive introduction to the process of urbanization, urban systems, the development of urban structures and urban governance. The problems in modern cities and urban problems in particular will be examined. Topics discussed include urbanization, urban systems, urban land use, urban housing market, urban services, urban governance, Chinese cities and world cities.
courses.learning_outcomes: Enable students to acquire specialized knowledge of urban geography and learn comprehensive approach in the study of urban geography. Students would develop a good understanding of urbanization process, urban system and urban governance and the ability to debate various contemporary urban issues confidently. Through various learning activities such as weekly reading, urban survey project and tutorials, the course will enhance students’ capabilities in various skills such as critical thinking, communication skills, data analysis, report writing and self-managed learning.

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Economic Geography
courses.description: Understanding uneven global development is an important agenda in geography and politics alike. In an era of globalization, the regional and national aspects of growth are continuously contested through both spatial (e.g. areas, their interactions and relationship with other areas) and aspatial (e.g. institutional and political factors) processes. This course will provide an overview of key economic-geographical theories and concepts in analyzing economic processes at various geographical scales. To this end, the relationships between space, economy and society will be discussed using a number of cases. Topics cover globalization and local development, and how they work together to shape spatial organization and economic change, location of production and transnational corporations, and spatial interaction and network. The course provides an excellent vehicle toward understanding today’s increasingly interdependent world.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, the student should be able to

•Describe the goals, concepts, and subject matter of economic geography

•Related theories from economic geography to interpret the economic geography of specific places and to understand economic problems their encounter in daily life.

•Assess how economic processes help to structure specific places and the lives of people living in those places.

•Understand how economic processes connect their own lives to those of others and how economic choices they make affect the lives of other people.

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Sustainable Development

meetings.instructor:
Professor Jack Laurie HARRIS, 
Professor LU Xingcheng

Professor Jack Laurie HARRIS, 
Professor LU Xingcheng

courses.description:
(UGEC2171 is double-coded with GRMD2401.)

Sustainable development is a global vision for the future. This approach to development should not only generate economic growth, but also distribute its benefits equitably, regenerate the environment rather than destroy it, as well as empower people rather than marginalize them.

The UN 2030 Agenda came into effect in 2015 promising to “interlink and integrate” Sustainable Development Goals in an attempt to implement solutions facing humanity. Sustainable development goals are an all-inclusive invitation to act to end poverty, secure the planet and ensure that all people appreciate peace and prosperity.
This course introduces the concept of sustainable development, the evolution of models and the implicit assumptions they make, as well as their contradictions. It also traces the advent of the SDGs and the extent that they support the principles of sustainable development. We examine the emergence of environmental problems and critically review the institutional responses to these problems since the late 1960s. We then consider in detail the increasingly popular idea of efforts in the pursuit of the SDGs from different perspectives that centres around people, planet, prosperity, peace and the partnerships involved in achieving the goals. The lectures will explore how achieving sustainable development goals will depends much on effective planning and good governance. Examples from different parts of the world will be used to underline the tight inter-connections between processes in different regions and across geographical scales in the context of sustainable development.

GRMD2401 is double-coded with UGEC2171.
Not for students who have taken UGEC2171, 2354 or 2775.
courses.course_attributes:
SDG-GE #1 No Poverty
SDG-GE #2 Zero Hunger
SDG-GE #3 Good Health and Well-being
SDG-GE #6 Clean Water and Sanitation
SDG-GE #7 Affordable and Clean Energy
SDG-GE #10 Reducing Inequality
SDG-GE #11 Sustainable Cities and Communities
SDG-GE #12 Responsible Consumption and Production
SDG-GE #13 Climate Action
SDG-GE #15 Life On Land
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to Sustainable Development: Origin and Evolution

(To introduce why we need sustainable development, the history of sustainable development, and Sustainable Development Goals.)

2. Planetary Boundary (SDG 13 – Climate Action, SDG 15 – Life on Land)

(To introduce the basic concept of the nine planetary boundaries, such as climate change, ocean acidification, and novel entities.)

3. Ecosystem Services, Ecological Footprint and Carbon Footprint (SDG 13 – Climate Action, SDG 15 – Life on Land)

(To introduce the four important ecosystem services provided by the natural environment; to show how to perform simple ecological footprint and carbon footprint evaluation.)

4. Global Challenges of Sustainable Development I (SDG 1 – No Poverty, SDG 7 – Affordable and Clean Energy)

(To discuss the development challenges, such as the problems related to poverty, energy usage, and environmental problems.)

5. Global Challenges of Sustainable Development II (SDG 3 – Good Health and Well-Being, SDG 10 – Reduced Inequalities)

(To discuss the development challenges, such as the problems related to gender equality and health.)

6. Policy for Sustainable Development (SDG 10 – Reduced Inequalities, SDG 13 – Climate Action)

(To introduce different types of policy tools, such as market-based approaches and voluntary agreements.)

7. Urban Sustainability I (SDG 11 – Sustainable Cities and Communities)

(To introduce some of the important aspects in sustainable city, such as smart mobility and green roof.)

8. Urban Sustainability II (SDG 11 – Sustainable Cities and Communities)

(To introduce the basic concept of green building and Building Environmental Assessment Method in Hong Kong.)

9. Rural Sustainability (SDG 2 – Zero Hunger, SDG 6 – Clean Water and Sanitation)

(To introduce some methods in sustainable agriculture, such as hydroponics and aquaponics; to discuss the methods that can help to achieve the sustainable rural livelihood.)

10. Linear Economy and Circular Economy (SDG 12 – Responsible Consumption and Production)

(To introduce the basic concepts of the linear economy, circular economy and life cycle assessment.)

11. Sustainable Future (SDG 7 – Affordable and Clean Energy, SDG 11 – Sustainable Cities and Communities)

(To introduce some of the novel techniques that can contribute to sustainable development.)

12. Group Presentation I

13. Group Presentation II

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Natural Resource Management
courses.description: Given that humankind worldwide depends on natural resources for survival, the course will provide an overview of the principles of natural resource management. The course will specifically be useful to students interested in understanding the issues associated with use and misuse of natural resources. Lectures, field trips, seminars and study assignments will be used to focus attention and help analyze natural resources according to biotic resources, physical and earth resources and the social sciences, by identifying principles and practices used to organize natural resources for human use. Understanding these principles will allow for environmentally sound management of natural resources. The understanding of the physical and earth resources will facilitate the prudent management of resources such as land, water, waste. Applying social sciences systems of inquiry will prepare students for understanding the management, administration and policy issues that could affect humanities use of natural resources, globally, regionally and locally.
courses.course_syllabus:
Lecture 1: Synopsis of Resource, Natural Resources and Natural Resource Management
Lecture 2: Evolution of Resources and Natural Resource Management
Lecture 3: Dealing with Ecosystem Management in Natural resource Management
Lecture 4: Methods of Evaluation in Natural resource Management: INRMP
Lecture 5: Sacred forests and Indigenous Management
Lecture 6: Wetland, Aquaculture and Fish Ecology: Guest Speaker.
Reading Week (Preparation of a conceptual framework for the INRMP)
Lecture 7: Conservation management and Adaptive management: A choice of convenience
Lecture 8: Class Forum (Presentation of the conceptual framework for the INRMP)
Lecture 9: Tangible use of natural resources: Food Security, food management and slow food
Lecture 10: Intangible use of natural resources: Protected Areas and parks management
Lecture 11: Community participation and perspectives on natural resource management
Lecture 12: Students presentation of the INRM projects

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Nature Conservation in Hong Kong
courses.description:
(UGEB2113 is double-coded with GRMD2403.)

This course aims at providing students with an overall view on nature conservation in general and Hong Kong in particular. It will examine the history and development of nature conservation in Hong Kong including legislation, designation and management of the protected areas. Specifically, country, marine parks and geopark are developed to protected terrestrial and marine habitats as well as the associated wildlife, and geodiversity, respectively. Threats and problems facing existing protected areas will be discussed. Nature conservation will be addressed through lectures, field trips and students’ projects. It will also introduce concepts and principles of nature conservation in the local and global context, including climate change, ecosystem services, geo-conservation and the global conservation efforts such as the World Summit and Convention of Biodiversity. The course helps students look at nature conservation from the perspective of sustainable development, incorporating the environmental, social and economic dimensions of development, focusing on SDG Goals 14 and 15 in particular. Both SDGs are directly linked to nature conservation efforts, focusing on preserving natural resources, ecosystems, and biodiversity, which are vital for the health of our planet, ensuring sustainable fishing/forest management practices for the benefit of communities.
courses.course_attributes:
SDG-GE #14 Life Below Water
SDG-GE #15 Life On Land
courses.learning_outcomes:
* *Students should be able to achieve the following at the end of the course:**

* **Understand the situation of nature conservation in Hong Kong;**
* **Describe and explain concepts and principles of nature conservation in local and global context;**
* **Able to explain how protecting marine and country parks contributes to biodiversity conservation, geodiversity conservation and the sustainable use of natural resources;**
* **Explore the process in the formation of local nature conservation policy and practices;**
* ****Understand the role of conservation policies and practices in promoting environmental sustainability and achieving the SDGs;****
* **Appreciate and differentiate values and benefits of protected areas to the community;**
* **Identify viable measures in conserving habitats and ecosystems in Hong Kong; and**
* **Analyze strengths and weaknesses of various conservation measures applied in Hong Kong.**
courses.course_syllabus:
* *Course themes**

* *Part 1. Nature Conservation**

* Key concepts - What is nature? Why nature conservation? Nature conservation and Hong Kong
* Man and the environment - Relationship between human and nature, Environmental movement
* Nature conservation in Hong Kong - History, Protected areas in Hong Kong, Implications and lessons learnt
* Protecting marine and terrestrial ecosystems is related to SDG14 (life below water) and SDG15 (life on land)

* *Part 2. Protected area I: Country park**

* Design - From conservation to sustainable development, Park design and infrastructure, land use and enclaves
* Recreation impact and management - Facilities and services, Patterns of recreational use of country parks, Visitor management
* Threats and Challenges - Threats to nature conservation, Zoning and park design, Onsite and offsite management
* Afforestation - Afforestation and plantation, Woodland conservation
* Country Park plays an important role in advancing several SDGs (3, 6, 11,15) by conserving natural ecosystems and promoting sustainable resource use

* *Part 3. Protected area II: Marine park**

* Conservation of marine habitats/species
* Management of marine habitats
* Conservating marine environments through marine park contributes to the well-being of both marine life (SDG14) and human communities (SDG3)

* *Part 4. Protected area III: Geopark**

* Geo-conservation in Hong Kong
* Social and economic benefits
* UNESCO Global Geoparks promote sustainable local economic growth through sustainable tourism (SDG8)

* *Part 5. Conservation policy**

* Development pressure and development control
* Administrative options
* Nature conservation in the 21st century
* Biodiversity Strategy and Action Plan of Hong Kong
* Bottom-up approach to nature conservation
* The role of green groups, local people and other stakeholders

* *Course lectures under each theme:**

* *1. Nature Conservation**

* Course introduction
* Man and the environment
* History of nature conservation

* *2. Protected area I: Country park**

* Protected area I: Country parks
* Recreation management
* Management challenges
* Afforestation

* *3. Protected area II: Marine park**

* Protected area II: Marine park

* *4. Protected area III: Geopark**

* Protected area III: Geopark

* *5. Conservation policy**

* Conservation policy
* Nature conservation: an outlook
* Nature conservation in action

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Energy and Society
courses.description: The historical evolution of the human society is significantly affected by how we consume energy. Our modern society is built on modern energy consumption patterns. However, rising energy consumption also raises serious environmental challenges that are detrimental to human beings and our planet Earth. Accordingly, one critical goal of energy development is to maximize the positive impacts and to minimize the negative impacts of energy consumption. After discussing the role of energy consumption in a society, this course will analyze how energy consumption and the environment affect each other. Students will then be guided through various levels of a society, from individuals, households, communities, to cities, countries and the world in general discussion and case studies on how energy is consumed. Recognizing the importance of energy conservation as a key solution, this course will further examine two major barriers, particularly the behavior and efficiency gaps, to understand how we could achieve the goal. An open and especially active mind is a must for success in this course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students are expected to be equipped with basic knowledge on energy consumption, from positive to negative impacts, from patterns to solutions. The course will train the students to approach problems with critical and creative thinking. Students will learn not only along the temporal dimension but also across various societies in the current world. Particular learning outcomes could be listed below:
 To understand major social, economic, political and environmental impacts of energy consumption
 To critically think about energy consumption in the real world from individual to global levels
 To examine how to achieve sustainable development from the perspective of energy consumption
 To learn basic analysis skills and design solutions on energy consumption and conservation
courses.course_syllabus:
The evolution of energy consumption
1. Historical evolution of energy consumption
2. Social impacts of energy consumption

The two-way linkage between energy consumption and the environment
3. Energy consumption and air pollution
4. Energy consumption and water
5. Energy consumption and climate change

Energy consumption and society
6. Energy consumption of an individual: activities, age, gender, income
7. Energy consumption of a household: sharing, housing, energy-related decision making
8. Energy consumption of a community: time spending, thermal comfort, weekly and seasonal cycles
9. Energy consumption of a city: commute, local climate
10. Energy consumption of a country: transportation network, industries, economic structure
11. Energy consumption of the world: energy and development

Energy conservation
12. The distance from lips to hands: the behavior gap
13. The distance from wallets to actions: the efficiency gap

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Theory and Practice of Smart Cities
courses.description: Smart cities have been practiced in many world cities in the last decade. The advancement of technology and innovation has enabled cities to become smarter. Hong Kong also published a blueprint for smart cities. In this course, we will introduce the latest practice of smart cities around the world and discuss emerging theories and debates on smart cities.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1: Rise of smart cities: a historical perspective

Week 2: Smart cities: A search for theories

Week 3: Technology, corporations, people, and smart cities

Week 4: Big data and smart cities

Week 5: Hong Kong’s smart cities blue print

Week 6: Field studies: Hong Kong Science and Technology Park – Smart City Platform

Week 7: Smart mobility

Week 8: Smart environment and smart living

Week 9: Smart people and smart economy

Week 10: Smart government

Week 11: Seminar: Smart City Digital Hub by Siemens

Week 12: Project presentation (best practices around the world) I

Week 13: Project presentation (best practices around the world) II
courses.feedback_evaluation: An early course evaluation survey will be conducted before mid-term exam and a final one will be conducted towards the end of the semester.

Students are required to participate in all activities throughout the trip and to submit an individual report afterwards.

courses.description: Field studies are an integral part of the study of geography and resource management. The benefits of field studies are enhanced by a study trip to a destination outside of Hong Kong. The destination of this trip is Oceania. The trip will study a range of topics related to geography and resource management, urban and regional development, and socio-environmental issues in Oceania. The objectives are three-fold: (1) to broaden students’ horizons and knowledge base through exposure to a different and less familiar environment outside Hong Kong; (2) to enable students to make comparative studies across different countries or regions; and (3) to provide an opportunity for students to interact with non-local scholars and students in the same discipline. This field trip course is held during term breaks under the supervision of one or more faculty members. The theme of the field trip can be one or more Concentration Area(s) under the programme curriculum. Students are required to participate in all activities throughout the course and submit individual and/or group-based assignments.

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Research Design and Methodology

meetings.instructor:
Professor Jack Laurie HARRIS, 
Professor LU Xingcheng

Professor Jack Laurie HARRIS, 
Professor LU Xingcheng

Professor Jack Laurie HARRIS, 
Professor LU Xingcheng

Professor Jack Laurie HARRIS, 
Professor LU Xingcheng

courses.description: This course introduces scientific research methods and skills in geography. It aims to offer an integrative and broad introduction to both qualitative and quantitative aspects of geographic research. The course covers hands-on issues in planning and implementing research, such as generating research ideas and justifying research topics, using library resources, establishing theoretical framework, selecting the research design and sampling standard, conducting fieldwork, collecting data, and analysing and presenting the results. In addition, this course also discusses the principles in evaluating the quality of a research. This course is organized into three modules. The first module introduces how a research topic and its relevant questions are set up, how to use the existing literature and various geographic theories to frame a research, and how to design fieldwork and sampling schemes. The second module introduces the qualitative methods in geographical research, such as conducting fieldwork, collecting and analyzing data, writing research findings, and dealing with ethical concerns. The third module covers quantitative methods in geographical research, such as data types and sources, sampling methods, questionnaire design, non-parametric tests, and analysis of variation (ANOVA).
courses.enrollment_requirement: GRMD2102 or another statistics course which is approved by the instructor as a pre-requisite.
courses.course_syllabus:
Module I – Research design in geography

1. Course introduction and overview

Nature of scientific research in geography

2. Formation of research topic

Use of literature

3. Use of geographical theories

4. Research design

Module II – Qualitative methods

5. Fieldwork instrument

Safety and ethics

6. Observation and interviewing

7. Analysis and writing

Module III – Quantitative methods

8. Data types & sources

9. Sampling methods

10. Questionnaire design

11. Non-parametric tests

12. Analysis of variation (ANOVA)
courses.feedback_evaluation:
• Qualitative feedback from student panels/ forums/ internet forums

• Early and final course evaluation

• Reflection of teachers

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Satellite Image Analysis
courses.description:
This course discusses the application of digital image processing techniques in
analyzing digital remote sensing data. Topics include: image preprocessing, image enhancement, image classification and accuracy verification.
courses.learning_outcomes: This course discusses the concept and application of digital image processing techniques in analysing digital satellite data for geographical and environmental studies. Topics include: image preprocessing, image enhancement, image classification, accuracy verification and change detection. Upon completion of the course, students are expected to grasp basic understanding of the principle of digital remote sensing image analysis and how different processing techniques are applied in generating thematic information.
courses.course_syllabus:
Content and Lecture Schedule

* *Content and Lecture Schedule**

| **Week** | **Content** |
| --- | --- |
| 1 | Overview ·Principle of remote sensing ·Electromagnetic Radiation ·Electromagnetic Spectrum ·Spectral properties of terrestrial features |
| 2 | Satellite Remote Sensing ·Types of satellites ·Landsat ETM+ ·SPOT ·IKONOS, Quickbird, Worldview |
| 3 | Image Structure and Formats Image Resolution ·Spatial resolution ·Spectral resolution ·Radiometric resolution ·Temporal resolution Effect of resolutions on image analysis |
| 4 | Image processing systems ·Hardware and software ·PCI Geomatica system Image Display Methods ·Black and white display ·Pseudocolor display ·Color composite Image Enhancement ·Image histogram ·Linear Stretching |
| 5 | Image Enhancement ·Piecewise stretching ·Histogram equalization ·Image Matching |
| 6 | Image preprocessing ·Radiometric adjustment ·Geometric correction |
| 7 | Multispectral Transformation ·Image Ratioing ·Vegetation Indices |
| 8 | Multispectral Transformation ·Principal components analysis ·Tasseled cap transformation Hue-saturation-intensity transform Data Fusion |
| 9 | Spatial filtering ·Low pass filters ·High pass filters Textures |
| 10 | Logic of Image Classification Supervised classification I ·Procedures in classification ·Training set selection |
| 11 | Supervised classification II ·Feature Selection ·Classification Algorithms ·Parallelepiped classifier ·Euclidean distance classifier ·Maximum likelihood classifier ·Fuzzy classifier ·Neural Network classifiers |
| 12 | Unsupervised classification ·Spectral classes ·Clustering criteria ·Clustering algorithms Accuracy verification ·Spatial sampling ·Error matrix and interpretation |
| 13 | Change Detection ·Nature of changes ·Techniques for change detection |

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Advanced GIS
courses.description: This course covers major research and application issues in GIS. Topics include location allocation, route planning, spatial interpolation, 3D visualization, and web/wireless GIS. Through course project, lab sessions, and class discussions, it fosters an appreciation of GIS as an effective tool for solving complex geographical problems.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: GRMD2105.
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the end of the course, it is expected that the students will be able to:

• Synthesize and integrate concepts of GIS theory and methodology, including data models, GIS architectures, and spatial analysis.
• Develop an understanding of advanced spatial analytical functionalities, including spatial interpolation, route planning, and location-allocation
• Gain an understanding of GIS platforms other than desktop GIS
• Demonstrate a working knowledge to solve transportation and other geographical issues using GIS

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Cartography and Geovisualization
courses.description:
Map is an important tool to communicate spatial information based on which rational decisions can be made. Many geographic information system (GIS) related assignments are to produce maps, i.e. to present spatial data, process, and analytical results in form of map products. Cartographic knowledge and technique is a type of grammar that allows for the effective design and production of quality maps and other visual products. However, in recent decades, the process of map production is changing from supply to demand-driven and the function of maps emphasizes more on exploratory capability. Cartographers follow stipulated methods and techniques while incorporation of new ideas due to the emergent paradigm shift becomes equally important in map production. By adopting the five-step design thinking process, meaningful and innovative ideas can be generated in creating better maps for visual communication and exploration.

This course introduces the principles of cartography and design thinking process. Fundamental concepts of cartography include map projection and conventional map design theories such as colour theory, symbolization and map design will be covered in the first part of the course. The design thinking process including empathize, define, ideate, prototype and test is introduced and practiced associated with a map-making problem that is going to be solved by students in group. This course is taught with lectures, laboratories and interactive class activities. Lectures are designed to cover important theoretical concepts while the laboratories are implemented to provide students hands-on experience and skills on cartographic presentation and visualization using several software tools. Design thinking ideology is penetrated through the process of map production.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students are able to:
• attain knowledge about the theoretical concepts and methods of cartographic design and mapping;
• utilize a variety of thematic mapping technique in creating professional and quality cartographic products; and
• experience and learn about the design thinking process in cartographic design
courses.course_syllabus:
Cartography and Design Thinking
• Brief history and evolution of map
• Types of maps
• Scope of geovisualization
• Design thinking and cartography

Cartographic Basics
• Coordinate system
• Map projection
• Generalization

Cartographic Design I
• Colour theory
• Colour in cartographic design
• Symbolization

Cartographic Design II
• Visual hierarchy
• Scale
• Layout

Data Level and Classification
• Overview of mapping technique
• Classification methods
• Choropleth mapping

Visualizing Point Data
• Dot density
• Proportional symbols

Visualizing Line and Area Data
• Flow map
• Cartogram

Visualizing 3D Geospatial Information
• Defining 3D coordinate system
• 3D model building

Design Thinking: Empathize
• Project initiation
• Data/ Information collection

Design Thinking: Define and Ideate
• Define the problem
• Generation of creative solutions

Design Thinking: Prototyping
• Visualizing ideas
• Drafting map products

Design Thinking: Experimentation
• Testing of ideas and products
• Collecting feedbacks and revision

Finalizing Map Product
Presentation and Sharing

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Environmental Management
courses.description: This course critically examines the interrelations between human activities and the environment, analyses the nature and roots of environmental problems, evaluates the effectiveness of various environmental management options and discusses the complexities of environmental policy-making.
courses.learning_outcomes: At the end of course, students are expected to have developed the necessary data gathering, analytical, problem-solving and presentation skills in managing environmental problems and are able to evaluate and appreciate other’s viewpoint as well as presenting theirs.
courses.course_syllabus:
1

* *1.** **The Environmental** **Challenge and** **Policy** **Responses**

* *2.** **The Nature of Environmental Degradation**

* *3.** **Policy Considerations**

* **A.*** ***Dose‑Response Relationship and Environmental Standards***

* **B.*** ***Economic Analysis***

* **C.*** ***Ethics and Distributive Considerations***

* *4.** **Policy Instruments**

* **A.*** ***Command and Control Approach***

* **B.*** ***Economic Instruments***

* **C.*** ***Environmental Impact Assessment***

* *5.** **Issues in Environmental Management**

* **A. Managing Uncertainty***

* *B.** ***Siting Locally Unwanted Facilities***

* *C.** ***Conflict Management and Resolution***

* *D. *Wrapping Up the Course***
