a. Mitchell, B. (2002) 'Change, complexity, uncertainty and conflict', in Chapter 1,**Resource and Environmental Management**, pp. 1-25.

b. Rockstrom, J. (2009) ‘A safe operating space for humanity’**Nature**, Vol. 461(24), pp. 472-475.

b. Roque, C.R. (1986) 'Factors influencing environmental policies in developing countries', in Asian Development Bank (ed.)**Envi­ronmental Planning and Management**. Asian Development Bank. pp. 134‑83.

* *2.****The Nature of Environmental Degradation**

a. 環境保護編輯部(2010) ‘發達國家環保道路的啟示’, **環境保護**, Vol. 449, pp. 14-15.

b. Ostrom, E. (2008) ‘The challenge of common-pool resources’,**Environment**, Vol. 50(4), pp. 8-20.

c. Liu, J.C. & A.A. Leiserowitz (2009) ‘From red to green: environmental attitudes and behaviour in urban China’,**Environment**, Vol. 51(4), pp. 32-45.

* *3.****Policy Considerations**

* **A.******Dose‑Response Relationship and Environmental Standards***

a.Liu J.L.Y. & A.J. Hedley (1996) ‘Epidemiologic and economic analyses of the environment: examples dealing with Hong Kong’s air pollution’,**Asian J. Environmental Management**, Vol. 4(2), pp. 121-130.

b.Hedley, A.J., T.H. Tam, C.M. Wong and M. Mcghee (2005)**Air quality in Hong Kong and the impact of pollution on health 1988-2003**. Paper in preparation.

* **B.******Economic Analysis***

a. Carpenter, R. & J.A. Dixon (1985) 'Ecology meets Economics: A Guide to sustainable development',**Environment**, Vol. 27(5), pp. 6‑11; 27‑32.

b. Farrow, S. & M. Toman (1999) ‘Using benefit-cost analysis to improve environmental regulations’,**Environment**, Vol. 41(2), pp. 12-15; 33-38.

c. EnvironmentalProtectionDepartment (1998)**Study of Economic Aspects of Ambient Air Pollution on Health**.http://www.epd.gov.hk/epd/english/environmentinhk/air/studyrpts/effect\_econ\_amb\_ap.html.

* **C.******Ethics and Distributive Considerations***

a. Spash, C.L. (1993) 'Economics, ethics, and long-term environmental damages',**Environmental Ethics**, Vol. 15, 115-132.

b. Pearce, D.W. & R.K. Turner (1990) 'Environmental Ethics', in Pearce D.W. & R.K. Turner (eds.)**Economics of Natural Resources and Environment**, pp. 226‑231.

c. Ileme, J. (2003) ‘Equity, environmental justice and sustainability:Incomplete approaches in climate change politics**’,****Global Environmental Change**,Vol.13 (3),195-206.

* *4.****Policy Instruments**

* **A.******Command and Control Approach***

a. Heyes, A.G. (2000) ‘Making things stick: enforcement and compliance', D. Helm (ed.)**Environmental Policy: Objectives, Instruments and Implementation**, pp. 91-110, Oxford: Oxford U. Press.

b. Lo, C.W.H. (1995) ‘Environmental protection in Hong Kong amidst transition: Is Hong Kong ready to manage its environment by law’,**Environmental Management**, Vol. 19, pp. 331-344.

c. Helm, D. (2000) ‘Objectives, instruments, and institutions”, in D. Helm (ed.)**Environmental Policy: Objectives, Instruments and Implementation**, pp. 1-28, Oxford: Oxford U. Press.

* **B.******Economic Instruments***

a. UNEP (2009) ‘Introduction to Economic instruments’, in**Training Resource Manual – The Use of Economic Instruments for Environmental and Natural Resources Management**Module 5, pp. 113-122. Available<http://www.unep.ch/etb/areas/econInst.php>

b. Winpenny, J. (1998) ‘Application of economic instruments for environmental management’, in B. Nash et.al. (eds)**Environmental Management in Practice**Vol. 1, Chap 17, pp. 325-340, Routledge.

c. d. U.K. Department of Environment, Food & Rural Affairs (1999)**Economic Instruments for Water Pollution Discharges**, http://www.defra.gov.uk/environment/water/quality/econinst2/ (Examples of application of economic instruments to water quality management)

* **C.******Environmental Impact Assessment***

a. Petts, J. (1999) ‘Environmental impact assessment – overviews of purpose and process’, in Chapter 1,**Handbook of Environmental Impact Assessment**, Vol. 1, pp. 1-11. Blackwell Science

b. Au, W.K., and S. Hui (2004) ‘Learning by doing: EIA follow-up in Hong Kong’, in A. Morrison-Saunders and J. Arts (eds.)**Assessing Impact: Handbook of EIA and SEA Followup**, pp. 197-223. Earthscan.

c. Lam, K.C. & L. Brown (1997) ‘EIA in Hong Kong: Effective but Limited’,**Asian J. Asian Environmental Management**, Vol. 5(1), pp. 51-66.

d. Hopkinson, L. (2007)‘Case study of the EIA Ordinance’, in B. Leverett et.al. (eds.)**Idling Engine: Hong Kong’s Environmental Policy in a Ten Year Stall**, Chapter 10, Civic Exchange.

* *5.****Issues in Environmental Management**

* **A. Managing Uncertainty***

a. Mitchell, B. (2002) 'Monitoring and evaluation', in Chapter 13, B Mitchell,**Resource and Environmental Management**, pp. 318-344.

c. Johnson, R.J. & M. Scicchitano (2000)‘Uncertainty, risk, trust and information: public perceptions of environmental issues and willingness to take action’,**Policy Studies J.**, 28(3): 633-647.

d. Weiss, C. (2007) ‘Defining precaution’,**Environment**, Vol. 49(8), pp. 33-36.

* *B.*****Siting Locally Unwanted Facilities***

a. Dear, M (1992) ‘Understanding and overcoming the NIMBY syndrome’**, Journal of the American Planning Association**, 58(3), 288-300.

b. Shaw, Daigee (2005) ‘Visions of the future for facility siting’, in S. H. Lesbirel & D. Shaw (eds)**Managing Conflict in Facility Siting: An International Comparison**, Chap. 10, pp. 196-207, Edward Elgar.

c. Lisbirel, S.H. & D Shaw (2000) 'Facility siting: Issues and perspectives’**Columbia Earthscape: An Online Resource on the Global Environmental**.

* *C.*****Conflict Management and Resolution***

a. Mitchell, B. (2002) 'Alternative dispute resolution', in Chapter 11,**Resource and Environmental Management**, pp. 267-289.

b. van Asselt, H. & E. Wubben (1998) ‘Environmental conflict management’, in B. Nash*et.al.*(eds)**Environmental Management in Practice,**Vol. 1, Chap 23, pp. 436-456, Routledge.

c. Harashina, S. (1995) ‘Environmental dispute resolution process and information exchange’,**Environmental Impact Assessment Review**, Vol. 15, pp. 69-80.

* *D.** ***Wrapping Up the Course***

a. Adly, J.E. & R.N. Stavins (2008) ‘Climate policy architectures for post-Kyoto World’,**Environment,**Vol. 50(3), pp. 7-17.

b. Stern, P.C. (1992) ‘Psychological dimensions of global environmental change’,**Annual Review of Psychology**, Vol. 43, pp. 269-302.

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Urban Environmental Problems
courses.description: This course examines the nature of noise, air and water pollution problems in cities and discusses how these pollutants and the provision of open/green space can affect urban livability. Particular emphasis is placed on the use of prediction models to assist environmental assessment and planning.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After successfully completing the course, students will be able:

• To find information related to the urban environment;
• To identify and use appropriate techniques to solve urban environmental problems; and

• To become more sensitive and responsible to the environment.
courses.course_syllabus:
Environmental Challenges in Cities

Urban Climate - Basics and Problems

Urban Climate Assessment and Management

Noise Pollution

Noise – Basics, characterization, effects

Urban Noise Sources

Traffic Noise Modelling

Managing Urban Acoustic Environment

Air Pollution

Urban Air Quality- Trends and problems

Urban Air Quality Modelling

Managing Urban Air Quality

Water Pollution

Importance of Water Bodies in Cities

Water Pollution – Eutrophication and deoxygenation

(Tutors to provide feedback on the practicals and lab reports)

Water Quality Modelling and Applications

Urban Sustainability
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Early course evaluation

Course Evaluation

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Geomorphology
courses.description: Geomorphology is the scientific study of the Earth’s landforms and the processes that create them. The course covers theory and application of geomorphic processes (such as weathering, erosion, hillslope processes, river processes, coastal processes) and the associated landforms. Other than regular lecture sessions, field trips/laboratory will be arranged for the course to enable students to have a better understanding of different landforms and climatic settings.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introducing geomorphology

2. Plate tectonics

3. Volcanicity and landforms

4. Weathering and landforms

5. Soil erosion

6. Slope processes and forms

7. Fluvial processes and landforms

8. Coastal processes and landforms

9. Karst processes and landforms

10. Glacial processes and landforms

11. Applied geomorphology

12. Geomorphological techniques
courses.feedback_evaluation:
The course evaluation survey will be conducted in the third week and the second last week of the course respectively.

Students are also welcome to give feedback to the course teacher at any time in person or through email.
courses.required_readings:
* Bierman P.R. and Montgomery D.R. (2020) Key concepts in geomorphology (2nd Edition). Austin, Boston, New York, Plymouth: Macmillan Learning. UL GB401.5.B54 2020
* Harvey, A. (2022) Introducing Geomorphology (2nd Edition). Edinburgh: Dunedin Academic Press. UL GB406.H38 2022
* Huggett R.J. and Shuttleworth, E. (2023) Fundamentals of Geomorphology (5th Edition). London, England: Routledge. *[Online e-book available]*
courses.recommended_readings: Further recommended readings will be provided in the lectures.

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Soil Science
courses.description: This course examines the fundamental characteristics and properties of soils and their relationships with humans and the environment, with special emphasis on soils in Hong Kong and South China. The formation, uses, degradation, restoration and sustainable management of soils will be discussed and illustrated with examples. Both theory and application will be emphasized. Field trips and laboratory practicals are compulsory.
courses.learning_outcomes: After taking this course, students are expected to: (a) understand the general properties, formation and profile development of soils; (b) understand the importance of soils in food production, landscape planting, and mitigation of global warming; (c) interpret soil data and recommend remedial measures in planting; (d) understand the impact of acid rain and climate change on soils; (e) understand the genesis, degradation and management of tropical to subtropical soils in China that supports a population of 300 million people; and (f) apply the knowledge of soil science to other disciplines, including landscape ecology, geomorphology, hydrology and water resources, resource management, ecotourism, agriculture and forestry etc. There are no prerequisite requirements of students’ chemistry knowledge in this course.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Concepts and principles in soil science

2. Weathering and pedogenesis

3. Soil air-water relationship

4. Soil reaction and remediation

5. Mineral colloids and cation exchange capacity (CEC)

6. Anion exchange capacity (AEC) and plant nutrition

7. Soil organic matter and organic farming

8. Soil carbon sequestration as a mitigative measure of global warming

9. Sand culture for sports turf: Potentials and environmental risks

10. Practical soil problems in Hong Kong: Landscape planting and ecological restoration

11. Soils in south China: Genesis, degradation, remediation and management

12. World soil problems and management
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Early Course Evaluation

Course Evaluation
courses.required_readings: Brady, N.C., and R. R. Weil. (2007). The Nature and Properties of Soils. 14th edition, Prentice-Hall, New Jersey.

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Tourism Planning and Management
courses.description:
Tourism is a leading industry in the world and one that uses natural and cultural resources substantially. This course will provide students with knowledge and skills to understand, plan, develop and manage natural and cultural resources in an environmentally responsible manner.
Given the nature of tourism and tourists in different locations, a broad understanding of tourism planning, its role in the community, its impact on resources and the environment will be investigated. In this course, students will study both the social and environmental aspects to better understand the complexity of natural and social systems in order to benefit tourism and make tourism beneficial in the local, regional and global environment.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction and overview of Tourism Planning and Management

2. The Tourism System

3. Theory of Tourism and the destination life cycle

4. Sustainable Tourism development

5. Tourism relationship with the environment

6. Tourism in the Urban environment

7. The role of various constituents in Tourism planning and management

8. Tourism potential in China

9. Strategic planning in the tourism industry

10. Tourism planning and management and the host community

11. Tourism planning and management through an interactive case study

12. Zoning as a tool in tourism planning

13. The development and implementation of a management plan
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Primarily, feedback information will be collected from student as follows:

• Early Course Evaluation (at the beginning of the teaching semester)

• Course questionnaire

• Tailored questionnaire

• Reflection of teacher

• Final course evaluation

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Geography of China
courses.description: This course provides a comprehensive and systematic analysis of the topics related to the geography of contemporary China. Both physical and human aspects of China’s geography are discussed in the context of a changing China in a changing world. Topics include resources, environment; food supply, population; rural reform and development, urbanization, urban reform and globalization, industrialization and regional development.
courses.learning_outcomes: Enable students to acquire specialized knowledge of Geography of China and learn comprehensive approach in the study of China using geographical perspective. Students would develop a good understanding of urban and regional development, development trends and environment, and the impact of globalization on China. Students would develop the ability to analyze and debate various contemporary issues on China confidently. Through various learning activities such as weekly reading, China project and tutorials, the course will enhance students’ capabilities in various skills such as critical thinking, communication skills, data analysis, report writing and self-managed learning.
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics

# Topics

China and the World

Administrative regions

Changing population

Food supply and security

Rural reform and transition

Market reform and the state-owned enterprises

Environment and development in Western China

Globalizing China

Chinese urbanization

Regional development policy and regional inequality

Video watching forum

Shanghai and Yangtze River Delta

Hong Kong and Pearl River Delta

Hong Kong and Shenzhen: intercity competition and cooperation
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Qualitative feedback from students/tutors via informal interaction/WebCT forum

Early and final course evaluation results

Student performance in the class and examination

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Population and Migration
courses.description: This course will examine population growth, distribution and migration. The course will introduce the basic concepts and methods in spatial population analysis and examine various population issues. Topics include population growth and regulation, demographic transition and population ageing, internal and international migration, population and resources.
courses.learning_outcomes: This course will enable students to achieve the following: To master the basic concepts, theory and methods in population analysis; To discuss confidently on the challenging issues of population explosion and ageing in the world; To understand the reasons of population changes especially migration; Be able to conduct basic population analysis for a geographical region and know their wide applications; To be informed of the application of GIS and computing for population monitoring and analysis. Through various learning activities such as weekly reading, population project and tutorials, the course will enhance students’ capabilities in various skills such as critical thinking, communication skills, data analysis, report writing and self-managed learning.
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics

| Topics |
| --- |
| Population and Resources (Briefing on population project) |

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Cultural Geography
courses.description: This course covers key debates and theories in cultural geography. How do we distinguish between space and place? What is the relationship between spatial practices and operations of power? How can one critically read maps and decipher the ideological meaning of landscapes? The course will address both textual and material approaches in the field to analyze the relationship between spatiality, power and subjectivity. Cultural geography’s well-known concern with the construction of various spaces and places across multiple scales will be complemented with more contemporary trends towards exploring non-representational, hybrid geographies.
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Gain a critical and comprehensive understanding of the key concepts and major debates in contemporary cultural geography.

• Apply the concepts and theories of cultural geography to identify and analyze various configurations of socio-spatial dialectic; to reveal various actors and struggles behind the construction of cultural landscapes; to deconstruct intended meanings of maps.

• Explain the role of asymmetrical power relations in the production of social spaces and subject positions; observe the agency of the matter.

• Develop effective communication, critical reading and writing skills as well as experience of working in groups.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1. Culture and Geography

Mitchell, D. 2000. Culture wars: Culture is politics by another name. In Cultural geography: A critical introduction, 3 – 37. Oxford and Malden: Blackwell.

Tutorial 1.

Hall, S. 2003. The work of representation. In Representation: Cultural representations and signifying practices, 16 – 42. London, Thousand Oaks and New Delhi: SAGE.

Week 2. Imaginative Geographies

Sharp, J. P. 2009. Imagining the world, Knowledge and power. In Geographies of postcolonialism: Spaces of power and representation, 11 - 55. London, Thousand Oaks, New Delhi and Singapore: SAGE.

Tutorial 2.

Schein, L. 2002. Gender and internal Orientalism in China. In Chinese femininities / Chinese masculinities: A reader, 385-412. Berkeley, Los Angeles and London: University of California Press.

Week 3. Deconstructing Maps

Pickles, J. 2004. What do maps represent? The crisis of representation and the critique of cartographic reason. In A history of spaces: Cartographic reason, mapping and the geo-coded world, 27 - 60. London and New York: Routledge.

Tutorial 3.

Cosgrove, D. 2010. Counter-mapping and the death of cartography. In Rethinking the power of maps, 111 – 156. New York and London: Guilford Press.

Week 4. Landscapes of Power

Mitchell, D. 1996. California: The beautiful and the damned. In The lie of the land: Migrant workers and the California landscape, 13-36. Minneapolis and London: University of Minnesota Press.

Tutorial 4.

Donald, S. H. 2011. Landscapes of class in contemporary Chinese film: From Yellow Earth to Still Life. In Place of landscape: Concepts, contexts, studies, J. Malpas, (ed.), 227 – 245. Cambridge, Massachusetts and London, England: MIT Press.

Week 5. Social Relations and Spatial Practices

Shields. R. 1999. The production of space. In Lefebvre, love and struggle: Spatial dialectics, 141 – 185. London and New York: Routledge.

Tutorial 5.

Probyn, E. 2003. The spatial imperative of subjectivity. In Handbook of cultural geography, K. Anderson, M. Domosh, S. Pile and N. Thrift (eds), 290—299. London, Thousand Oaks and New Delhi: SAGE.

Week 6. Locating Place

Creswell, T. 2004. Genealogy of place. In Place: A short introduction, 15 – 51. Malden, Oxford and Carlton: Blackwell.

Tutorial 6.

Tuan, Y. F. Intimate experiences of place. 2001. In Space and place: The perspective of experience, 136 – 149. Minneapolis and London: University of Minnesota Press.

Week 7. Politics of Scale or Scalar Politics?

Leitner, H. 2004. The politics of scale and networks of spatial connectivity: Transnational interurban networks and the rescaling of political governance in Europe. In Scale and geographic inquiry: Nature, society, and method, E. Sheppard and R. B. McMaster (eds), 236 – 256. Malden, Oxford and Carlton: Blackwell.

Tutorial 7.

Marston, S. A., Jones III J. P. and Woodward, K. 2005. Human geography without scale. Trans Inst Br Geogr NS, 30: 416– 432.

Week 8. De- and Reterritorialization

Delaney, D. 2005. Entering the territory of territory. In Territory: A short introduction, 1 – 33. Malden, Oxford and Carlton: Blackwell.

Tutorial 8.

Jabareen, Y. 2015. The emerging Islamic State: Terror, territoriality, and the agenda of social transformation. Geoforum, 58: 51–55.

Week 9. B/ordering Practices

Sibley, D. 1995. Mapping the pure and the defiled. In Geographies of exclusion, 49 – 71. London and New York: Routledge.

Tutorial 9.

Smith, S. 2012. Intimate geopolitics: Religion, marriage, and reproductive bodies in Leh, Ladakh. Annals of the Association of American Geographers, 102 (6): 1511-1528.

Week 10. Regulation, Body and Discipline

Valentine, G. 1999. Imagined geographies: Geographical knowledges of self and others in everyday life. In Human geography today, D. Massey, J. Allen and P. Sarre (eds), 47-62. Cambridge, Oxford and Malden: Polity Press.

Tutorial 10.

Fanon, F. The fact of blackness. In Theories of race and racism: A reader, L. Back and J. Solomos (eds), 257-267. London and New York: Routledge.

Week 11. Migration, Religion and Belonging

Kong, L. 2001. Mapping ‘new’ geographies of religion: Politics and poetics in modernity. Progress in Human Geography, 25 (2): 211—233.

Tutorial 11.

Tse, J. (2011). Making a Cantonese-Christian family: Quotidian habits of language and background in a transnational Hongkonger church. Population, Space and Place, 17: 756–768.

Week 12. More-than-Human Geographies

Anderson, B. and P. Harrison. 2010. The promise of non-representational theories. In Taking-place: Non-representational theories and geography, Anderson, B. and P. Harrison (eds), 1- 34. Surrey and Barrington: Ashgate.

Tutorial 12.

Bear. C. 2012. Assembling the sea: materiality, movement and regulatory practices in the Cardigan Bay scallop fishery. cultural geographies, 20 (1): 21 –41.

Week 13. Materiality, Affect and Matter

Whatmore, S. 2002. Embodying the wild: Tales of becoming elephant. In Hybrid geographies: Natures, cultures, spaces, 35 – 59. London, Thousand Oaks and New Delhi: SAGE.

Tutorial 13.

Edensor, T. 2005. Materiality in the ruin: Waste, excess and sensuality. In Industrial ruins: Spaces, aesthetics and materiality, 97 – 125. Oxford and New York: Berg.

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Transport Geography
courses.description: Contemporary economic processes, such as the globalization of trade and the emergence of economic blocs, have been accompanied by significant growth in the movements of people and freight. This course provides a broad introduction to transport geography. Basic ideas in sustainable development will be related to the provision of infrastructure and services of transport and logistics at various geographical scales, and to the development of different modes of transport. The course will provide students with a foundation for more advanced treatments of the subject.
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics\*

## Topics\*

| **Week** | **Topic** |
| --- | --- |
| 1 | Introduction: mobility and accessibility |
| 2 | Transportation and Economic Development |
| 3 | Transport and Environment |
| 4 | Transport and Social Justice |
| 5 | Urban Transport |
| 6 | Inter-city and Regional Transport |
| 7 | Special topic on railway and high speed rail |
| 8 | Maritime Transport |
| 9 | Air Transport (1) |
| 10 | Air Transport (2) |
| 11 | Inter-modal Transport and Global Logistics |
| 12 | Student Presentations (your essay) |
| 13 | Future Trends and Course Review |

\* This is a tentative list of topics. Final topics may be changed by the instructor.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Two anonymous course evaluations (one in the fourth week and one in the last week) will be conducted to get feedback about the course from students.

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Urban and Regional Planning
courses.description: This course aims to provide students with a general understanding of a social science profession, a process of decision-making and a governmental function. The multidisciplinary nature of planning in the geographical, socio-economic and political contexts is stressed. Individual topics include planning theories, public participation, land use planning, development control, harbour reclamation, new town development and urban renewal.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students should be able to:

• compare and contrast different modes of planning.
• interpret planning as a process under specific temporal and spatial context.
• apply theoretical concepts to analyse real world planning issues.
• develop the skills necessary for interpreting different planning cases critically.
• relate local and regional planning issues to the wider global context for understanding and solutions.
• possess basic skills to work or further study in the field of urban planning.
courses.course_syllabus:
General Concepts
1. Introduction: What is Urban and Regional Planning?
2. Urban and Regional Planning: Public Interests versus Private Interests
3. The Planning Process
4. Planning Theories I
5. Planning Theories II
Topical Issues
6. Harbour Reclamation: The Production of Space
7. Urban Renewal: Conflicts and Struggle
8. New Town Planning
9. Heritage Conservation and Town Planning
10. Rural Planning and Development Control
11. Regional Tourism Planning: The Greater Pearl River Delta
12. Planning for World Cities
13. Sustainable Cities: Case Studies from MDCs and LDCs
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Early Course Evaluation
Course Evaluation
courses.required_readings:
### Recommended and Required Readings

\*Allmendinger, P. (2009) (2nd ed.), *Planning Theory.* Basingstoke: Palgrave.

Inskeep, E. (1991) *Tourism Planning: An Integrated and Sustainable Development Approach.* New York: Van Nostrand Reinhold, Chapter 2.

\*Jacobs, J. (2003) “The Death and Life of Great American Cities”. In Campbell, S. and Fainstein, S. (eds.), *Readings* *in Planning Theory.* Second Edition. Oxford: Blackwell Publishing, pp. 61-74. [From Jane Jacobs (1961), The Death and Life of Great American Cities, pp. 3-25].

\*Klosterman, R. E. (2003) “Arguments For and Against Planning”. In Campbell, S. and Fainstein, S. (eds.), *Readings* *in Planning Theory.* Second Edition. Oxford: Blackwell Publishing, pp. 86-101. [From Town Planning Review, 56 (1), (1985): 5-20].

Lai, W. C. (2000) ***Town Planning Practice: Context, Procedures and Statistics for Hong Kong.*** Hong Kong : Hong Kong University Press.

Lee, Joanna and Ng, M. K. (2007) “Planning for the world city” in Yeung, Y. M. (ed*.) The First Decade: Hong Kong SAR in Introspective and Retrospective Perspectives.* Hong Kong: The Chinese University Press. pp. 297-319.

Lee, Joanna and Tang, W.S. (2009) “Town Planning in Hong Kong: Public Interest versus Private Interest”. In Wong, K.K. (ed.) *Hong Kong, Macao and the Pearl River Delta: A Geographical Survey.* Hong Kong: Hong Kong Educational Publishing Company.

Levy, M. John (2011) (9th ed.), *Contemporary Urban Planning*. Boston : Longman, Chapter 19.

\* Required readings (Additional required readings for each lecture will be announced in class.)

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Energy Resources for Carbon Neutrality
courses.description:
Our modern society is built on modern energy consumption. However, rising energy consumption also raises serious environmental challenges that are detrimental to human beings and our planet Earth. On one hand, energy is a key foundation of our modern way of life. Electricity illuminates and operates the world. Modern transportation systems are energy intensive. The consumption of natural gas for cooking avoids indoor air pollution that is causing over one million premature deaths in poor countries. On the other hand, energy also creates many problems, such as air pollution, excessive water consumption and pollution, and most importantly, global climate change. Energy plays a crucial role in shaping the current global financial system through the petrodollar system, but also has frequently casted shadows on geopolitical and sometimes military conflicts. With a great majority of global CO2 emissions under national/regional carbon neutrality (or net zero) commitments, our utilization of energy resources will go through fundamental reforms. The ongoing energy transition away from fossil fuels and toward renewables is exerting profound influences on economic development, technological transformation and geopolitical disputes.

This course aims to guide students through a wide and interconnected array of real-world topics covering energy consumption, fossil fuels and non-fossil resources, and especially their impacts on and from carbon neutrality. Students are not required to have prior exposure to the field but should be open-minded in analyzing issues from alternative perspectives. The course will be taught from an interdisciplinary approach according to the nature of topics.
courses.learning_outcomes: After taking this course, students are expected to be equipped with comprehensive knowledge on energy and carbon neutrality management. Intensive data will be employed in the lectures. Students should learn the skills to present and analyze quantitative data. The course will train the students to approach problems with independent thinking. All continents and major countries will be covered and compared on energy and the environment as well their associated financial and geopolitical issues. Students will leave with a global view.
courses.course_syllabus:
Weekly topics (course syllabus):
1. Introduction to the topic and course overview
Concentration 1: Energy consumption
2. Energy consumption: how much and how
3. Energy consumption: the deciding factors
Concentration 2: Energy resources and supply
4. Coal
5. Oil & natural gas
6. Nuclear
7. Renewables
8. Electricity and electrification
Concentration 3: Energy and the environment
9. Energy and conventional air pollutants
10. Energy and climate change
11. The decarbonization of electricity generation
12. The decarbonization of transportation
13. Energy conservation

9. Energy and conventional air pollutants

* *\*****Coase, R. H., The Problem of Social Cost. *Journal of Law & Economics* 1960, *3* (Oct), 1-44.**

M.; Smith, K., The global burden of disease due to outdoor air pollution. *Journal of Toxicology and Environmental Health-Part a-Current Issues* **2005,** *68* (13-14), 1301-1307.

IEA, "Cleaner coal in China," Paris, France, 2009.

10. Energy and climate change

* *\*****Pacala, S. W.; Socolow, R. H., Stabilization Wedges: Solving the Climate Problem for the Next 50 Years with Current Technologies. *Science* 2004, *305* (5686), 968 - 972.**

Socolow, R. H.; Pacala, S. W., A plan to keep carbon in check. *Sci Am* **2006,** *295* (3), 50-57.

Xu, M.; Chang, C. P.; Fu, C. B.; Qi, Y.; Robock, A.; Robinson, D.; Zhang, H. M., Steady decline of east Asian monsoon winds, 1969-2000: Evidence from direct ground measurements of wind speed. *J Geophys Res-Atmos* **2006,** *111* (D24)

11. The decarbonization of electricity generation

* *\*****Lindley, D., The Energy Storage Problem. *Nature* 2010, *463* (7277), 18-20.**

IEA and NEA, *Projected Costs of Generating Electricity 2010*. Paris, France: OECD, 2010.

Kahn Ribeiro, S., S. Kobayashi, M. Beuthe, J. Gasca, D. Greene, D. S. Lee, Y. Muromachi, P. J. Newton, S. Plotkin, D. Sperling, R. Wit, P. J. Zhou, 2007: Transport and its infrastructure. In Climate Change 2007: Mitigation. Contribution of Working Group III to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change [B. Metz, O.R. Davidson, P.R. Bosch, R. Dave, L.A. Meyer (eds)], Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, United Kingdom and New York, NY, USA.

13. Energy conservation

* *\*****Dietz, T.; Gardner, G. T.; Gilligan, J.; Stern, P. C.; Vandenbergh, M. P., Household actions can provide a behavioral wedge to rapidly reduce US carbon emissions. *Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America* 2009, *106* (44), 18452-18456.**

Allcott, H.; Mullainathan, S., Behavior and Energy Policy. *Science* **2010,** *327* (5970), 1204-1205.

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: World Development
courses.description: This course offers a geographical perspective on imbalanced growth and development in both developing and developed countries and regions. It covers the concepts, theories, indicators, practices as well as issues and policies related to world development. Case studies from a number of countries/regions are used to advance the understanding of development paths and problems in the world.
courses.course_syllabus:
* *Section I Conceptualizing development**

1. Introducing world development: A geography perspective
2. From colonialism to globalization
3. Theories and strategies of development
4. Measurements and indicators of development

* *Section II Practice and space of development**

5. Population, resource and environment
6. Institutions of development
7. Aid and development
8. Rural and urban space

* *Section III Emerging themes**

9. Digital technologies and world development
10. Gender and world development
11. Climate change and world development
12. Health emergency, disaster risk management and world development
13. & 14. Field trips
courses.feedback_evaluation:

Course evaluation
Continuous feedback from students

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Natural Hazards and Human Responses
courses.description: This course adopts an interdisciplinary approach to examining the causes and characteristics of natural hazards and their effects on human society. It aims to present an overview and analysis of human settlement, planning and policy in relation to natural hazards in the light of their socio-economic impacts. Major geological, meteorological, hydrological, and ecological hazards will be addressed from physical science perspective. The interaction between nature, society, and technology will be analysed as we discuss how people and places experience and cope with natural hazards in terms of risk assessment, reduction of vulnerability, and disaster mitigation and management, etc. While the coverage will be broad and global, case studies of threats, occurrence and consequences of natural hazards in Hong Kong and Mainland China will be emphasized.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To improve the students’ understanding of the man-environment relationship in the context of risk, vulnerability, and disaster caused by natural hazards

2. To gain basic knowledge of geophysical concepts and principles of extreme natural events for understanding their causes, characteristics, and geographical distribution

3. To learn how environmental risk arises from the complex interaction between the physical environment and human society, and

4. To evaluate how social, economic, technological, and cultural factors affect the perception, prevention, and mitigation of natural hazards in different societies
courses.course_syllabus:
• Definition, classification, and global distribution of natural hazards

• Disaster risk as a result of hazard and vulnerability

• Vulnerability of society: prevention, mitigation and preparedness

• Population growth and global environmental change: Is the world becoming more vulnerable?

• Causes and effects of geological hazards (earthquakes, tsunamis, volcanic eruptions, avalanches and landslides)

• Causes and effects of meteorological hazards (typhoons, tornadoes, storms)

• Causes and effects of hydrological hazards (floods, droughts and famines)

• Causes and effects of ecological hazards (soil erosion, desertification)

• Planning and emergency action in developing and developed countries

Study topics of students’ interests and choices are not geographically limited to Hong Kong, but topics of local and regional relevance are encouraged. Part I of this two-course sequence (GRMD 4001, 4002) concentrates on the formulation of a research problem, proposal writing, research design and data collection. Part II aims at data analysis/laboratory experiments, interpretation of analytical/experimental results and thesis writing.

courses.learning_outcomes:
This is a capstone course that trains students to integrate the knowledge and skills acquired in the final year of studies. The learning outcomes are as follows:

•Students will be able to acquire and condense specific geographical and resource management knowledge through independent and in-depth investigation and research,
•Students will gain experiences and develop capability of applying a wide range of geography and resource management research methods, and

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Special Topics in Geography and Resource Management I
courses.description: This course provides an in-depth analysis of specific topics in geography, resource utilization and management that supplements other courses offered by the Department. The topics selected are of great significance to the sustainability of mankind. The content of the course will vary with the instructor. Important topics will include the theoretical background of the geographical and resource management issues concerned, geographical analysis using the latest geographical techniques, evaluation of resource availability and scarcity, optimal resource utilization and management.

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: GIS Workshop
courses.description: This course emphasizes hands-on experience in GIS. Lectures will cover the concepts of software engineering, GIS design methods, system analysis and case study. Students are required to design an applied GIS to tackle specific geographical problems.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: GRMD2105.
courses.learning_outcomes:
The GIS Workshop covers the basic principles of GIS project design and an independent project to be conducted by the students. Tutorials on GIS customization will also be provided. Students will develop and demonstrate competence in using and developing GIS techniques in a substantive application to their field of interest.

At the end of the course, students are expected to:

• Understand the principles of GIS Design using Structured System Analysis and Design Method

• Gain familiarity with the methods for customizing GIS

• Develop competence in implementing a GIS-based application system
courses.course_syllabus:
The projects will be identified by the student and approved by the tutor and instructor during the first six weeks of class. From the seventh week onward, students are expected to work independently, using the university computer labs or facilities off-site as needed to complete their chosen project. After nine weeks, the class will meet at mid-semester for students to discuss project progress and demonstrate provisional results to the class, and at the end of the semester to present their final results.

Schedule:

6th week Detailed proposals due.

9th week Mid-term presentations

13th week Final presentations

14th week All project deliverables due on or before

To help students understand the basic principles of GIS customization, the following tutorials will be provided by the tutor:

Tutorials

Tutorial 1. Introduction to ArcMap, ArcObjects and VBA

Tutorial 2. Developing ArcGIS applications with ArcObjects

and ArcMap Customization

Tutorial 3. Using ArcMap maps and layers with VBA

Tutorial 4. Using ArcMap data windows and page layouts with VBA

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Hydrology and Water Resources
courses.description: This course aims to offer students a broad exposure to the basic concepts and principles of hydrological science and thus to help them understand various technical and policy issues in water resources management. Focus is placed on all components of the hydrological cycle and the integration of hydrological processes for understanding runoff generation mechanisms at the hillslope and watershed scales. The concept and analysis of water balance are emphasized throughout the course. Principles and techniques of water resources management are also introduced, along with case studies in mainland China and Hong Kong.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Through a variety of teaching and learning activities, students will be expected to achieve the outcomes of understanding the concepts, basic principles, and applications on the following topics in the studies of hydrology and water resources.

1. hydrologic cycle and the role of water in the physical and environmental systems

2. characteristics, processes, and estimation of major components of hydrologic cycle

3. interaction of various hydrologic components and its influence on water availability

4. water resources in Hong Kong, mainland China and the world
courses.course_syllabus:
Introduction to hydrologic science

Hydrologic cycle and water resources

Properties of water as a physical substance

Hydrologic quantities and units

Professional associations and scientific journals for hydrologists

Precipitation and interception

Formation and types of precipitation

Measurement of precipitation

Point and areal precipitation

Double mass and frequency analysis

The components of interception

Influence of vegetation properties on interception

Soil moisture and infiltration

Hydraulic properties of soils

Soil-water relationships

Soil moisture release curve

Measurement and calculation of infiltration

Evaporation and transpiration

Processes of evaporation and transpiration

Estimating evaporation

Potential and actual evapotranspiration

Thornthwaite climatic water budget

Monthly water budget bookkeeping technique

Runoff generation and streamflow

Runoff components and generation

Streamflow measurement and calculation

Stage-discharge rating curve

Hydrograph components and analysis

SCS Runoff Curve Number technique

Rational method for peak flow estimation of urban watersheds

Groundwater storage and flow

Groundwater system and its interaction with surface water

Characterization of groundwater flow

Wells and groundwater protection

Water Resources Management

Water as a resource and water use

Water management approaches

Total water management in Hong Kong

Water resources in China

World water resources

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Ecosystem Restoration and Management
courses.description: With increasing human population and diminishing natural resources, environmental degradation is a growing concern globally. Recently, there is a call for an ecological approach to replace the rigid engineering and technological approach to solve the world’s environmental problems in a more sustainable manner. This course will introduce the principles and practice of ecological engineering in restoring disturbed ecosystems and creating new ecosystems that provide benefits to both humans and the environment, using a combination of global and local case studies. Students will integrate the knowledge of ecology and other fields of physical geography, e.g. hydrology and soil science, to examine holistically the influence of natural and anthropogenic perturbations on the structure and functions of terrestrial, wetland and aquatic ecosystems. Field trips will be conducted to enhance the students’ learning experience and technical skills in an outdoor setting.
courses.learning_outcomes: By the end of the course, students are expected to be able to: (a) master the concepts of ecosystems as a dynamic system; (b) understand the concepts and practice of ecological engineering in designing a sustainable ecosystem that is beneficial to both the natural environment and human society; (c) develop an ecologically sound strategy to restore landscapes degraded by fire, drainage, excavation, and other human activities; (d) demonstrate analytical skills in evaluating the success of ecological restoration projects; (e) apply observational and measurement techniques in the field to assess the ecological conditions of different ecosystems.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction
2. Ecological Engineering and Ecosystem Restoration
3. Ecosystem Principles and Concepts
4. Wetland Ecology
5. Wetlands and Climate Change
6. Treatment Wetlands
7. Wetland Rehabilitation and Creation
8. Restoration of River and Lake Ecosystems
9. Restoration of Degraded Landscapes
10. Fire Ecology
11. Post-fire Restoration of Forests
12. Green Roof as an Ecological System

courses.title: Environmental Planning and Assessment

courses.description: The course introduces and examines the theories, processes and methodologies of environmental planning and assessment as important tools and instruments for minimizing human impacts on the environment and achieving environmental sustainability through good governance. Environmental planning plays a vital role in urban design and the formulation of land use and other planning strategies in order to mitigate the effects of human activities on air, water, land, and ecological systems, and to promote sustainable use of energy, water and other natural resources. While the coverage is broad and comprehensive, emphasis will be placed on the two most prominent tools, i.e. Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) and Strategic Environmental Assessment (SEA), in terms of their origins, legal and regulatory requirements, and practices around the world. After introducing the conceptual framework and theoretical foundation of environmental assessment, specific methods and techniques (both qualitative and quantitative) will be introduced for students to understand the procedures and systems and gain the technical skills for practical applications. Environmental planning considerations and impact assessment will be examined for different sectors (industry, commercial, transportation, etc.) and multiple environmental media (air, water, solid waste, and noise) at difference spatial scales (local, regional, and national). Although a global perspective and comparative approach will be adopted throughout the course, examples and case studies of mitigating and managing environmental impacts through planning and assessment will mainly come from Hong Kong and mainland China.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To understand basic concepts and theories of environmental planning and assessment as important tools for minimizing environmental impacts and consequences of human activities,

2. To learn how legal, regulatory and institutional systems work together to influence and face the environmental planning challenges,

3. To gain technical skills and practical experiences of investigating environmental planning problems and assessing impacts, and

4. To develop holistic approaches to integrate social, political, and economic considerations into environmental planning and assessment processes.
courses.course_syllabus:
• Course Briefing and General introduction to environmental planning and assessment

• Elements, approaches and methodologies of environmental assessment

• Introduction to Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA), and its processes, tools and methods

• Tools, methods and techniques for impact prediction and assessment 1

• Tools, methods and techniques for impact prediction and assessment 2

• Environmental Impact Assessment at the international level

• Transboundary Environmental Impact Assessment

• Overview of Strategic Environmental Assessment (SEA)

• Evaluating the SEA of Landuse Use Plans

• The practice of SEA in different countries

• Cost-Benefit Analysis and the valuation of environmental impacts

• Social Impact Assessment and Risk Assessment

• Cumulative Effects Assessment and Life-Cycle Assessment

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Hong Kong Geographical Issues
courses.description: This is an advanced course organized in seminar and workshop formats. Emerging geographical issues in Hong Kong related to land and water resources, transport and infrastructure development, housing and population policies, urban poverty, urban renewal, regional cooperation etc., will be selected for discussion and debate. The issues discussed will change from time to time in response to the changes in Hong Kong. Students are required to submit an issue-based investigation report at the end of the course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students are expected:

• to have thorough understanding on selected geographical issues

• to learn how to formulate problem, identify issues, undertake research and synthesize information

• to be capable of developing necessary skills for the analysis of geographical issues

• to obtain a basic proficiency in presentation and communication skills

Reflection on the Issue-based Learning

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Urban Planning Workshop
courses.description: The course introduces the legal frameworks, regulations, procedures and techniques of urban planning in the context of Hong Kong. Students will engage in group-projects involving district and community level planning issues. Through hands-on experience of urban planning projects, the students will understand urban planning framework and techniques, and acquire practical skills in urban planning.

After taking this course, students are expected:

• to be familiar with the urban planning practice in Hong Kong

• to be capable of undertaking site appraisal; contextualizing planning problems; consolidating public views and making recommendations

• to apply concepts and theories into practice

• to obtain a basic proficiency in presentation and communication skills

• to be able to produce a comprehensive planning strategy for an area

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Methods for Resource Evaluation and Planning
courses.description: This course introduces basic methods of resource evaluation and planning, giving special emphasis to cost-benefit analysis and economic policies for the management of natural resources. The course covers the different approaches developed by practitioners to give an economic value to environmental assets, discussing the theoretical underpinnings and methodological constraints of each approach, with examples from around the world. To strengthen understanding, the students are given the opportunity to carry out the economic evaluation of an environmental amenity in Hong Kong. The course also considers the problems of resource management, with a review of the methods developed by economists to encourage a more sustainable use of our natural resources.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After successfully completing this course, the students will be able to:

•Understand the basics of resource evaluation and planning
•Understand the differences between the various methods of resource evaluation, and grasp the assumptions behind each method, as well as the limitations and potentials of each method.
•Critically examine studies undertaken by scholars; be able to criticize and suggest ways to improve these studies.
•Develop analytical and critical thinking capabilities through the discussion of various case studies and current issues

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Urban Big Data Analysis and Application
courses.description: Urban areas, where nearly 70% of world’s population is projected to live and thrive in 2050, rely on loads of data to run smoothly every day. The concept of smart city brings together the innovative use and management of data and advancement of computational technology. The collected data are so massive and varied, coined as “Big Data”, that require novel techniques to store, process and analyse to support various applications in urban areas with a view to improve people’s lives in cities. This course is divided into two parts. The first part will introduce the fundamental concepts, methods and platforms to analyse urban big data. The second part will discuss the application of big data in various urban topics including urban planning, transportation, energy, extreme events and public health issues. Students will be equipped with knowledge and skills on big data analytics to deal with real-world challenges.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students are able to:
• attain knowledge on the fundamental concepts and principles of big data, data mining and machine learning;
• acquire skills of the computing environment for big data and data analytics including hardware, software, distributed systems, and analytical tools; and
• understand the application of big data to various urban and geographical issues.
courses.course_syllabus:
1 Introduction to big data, data mining and machine learning
2 Source, collection, storage of urban big data
3 Big data analytics
4 Big data analysis algorithms I (Analytics using Hadoop)
5 Big data analysis algorithms II (Analytics using Spark)
6 Graph analytics
7 Big data visualization
8 Overview of big data analysis and smart city applications
9 Big data analytics for urban planning
10 Big data analytics for sustainable mobility and transportation
11 Big data analytics for urban energy systems
12 Big data analytics for extreme events and urban resilience
13 Big data analytics for urban public health and health care
14 Potential and challenges of big data for urban sustainability
courses.feedback_evaluation:
• Students’ reaction during the lecture
• Students’ feedback and suggestion from Blackboard forum
• Informal interaction with students and tutors
• Student performance in the class and laboratory
• Course evaluations

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Smart City Policies and Governance
courses.description: This course investigates the development of smart cities from a social science perspective. It introduces critical theories on the relationships between the development, governance and technological innovation of cities, examines the policy interventions required to promote and manage smart city development, analyses the contributions and challenges of smart city development to urban governance, and evaluates the performance of smart city initiatives in Hong Kong and other cities.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1: Introduction: Technology and the city

Week 2: Urban governance: Concepts and trends

Week 3–4: Urban innovation: Theories and policies

Week 5–6: Data and the city: Dashboard governance and data politics

Week 7–8: Smart economy in a smart city

Week 9–10: Smart city as sustainable city

Week 11–12: The right to the smart city

Week 13: Smart urbanism in Hong Kong: An appraisal

Week 14: Conclusion: For or against the smart city?
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students’ feedback will be collected through Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) exercises in Weeks 3 and 14 respectively.

• Coletta, C., Evans, L., Heaphy, L. and Kitchin, R. (Eds.) (2019). Creating smart cities. Abingdon, UK: Routledge.

• Marvin, S., Luque-Ayla, A., & McFarlane, C. (Eds.) (2016). Smart urbanism: Utopian vision or false dawn? Abingdon, UK: Routledge.

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Basic Issues of Geographical Research
courses.description: This course aims to introduce the basic elements and methodology of geographical research and prepare the students to excel in academia, research and related fields. It will cover some general topics related to the conduct of academic research, including the formulation of research problems, the substantiation of research arguments, the design of geographical research methodologies, the writing of scientific papers, and the dissemination of research findings. It will also cover some practical topics that are useful for the graduate students to succeed in completing their study on time. This course will be conducted largely in a seminar format requiring active in-class participation by students.

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Statistical Applications in Geography
courses.description: This course is an introduction to statistical methods in geographic research. The goal of this course is to provide a practical understanding of the application of statistical analysis to geographic problem-solving. Emphasis is placed on the application of appropriate methods to analyse geographic data, the appropriate procedures for research design, and the interpretation of research results. The course will cover the following topics: (1) geographical data and data manipulation; (2) correlation analysis; (3) multiple linear regression; (4) logistic regression; (5) principal components analysis; (6) factor analysis; (7) cluster analysis; and (8) discriminant analysis.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Geography and Resource Management
courses.course_syllabus:
Course syllabus:

1. Geographical data manipulation

2. Matrix algebra

3. Correlation analysis

4. Autocorrelation analysis

5. Linear regression analysis

6. Stepwise regression analysis

7. Geographically weighted regression analysis

8. Logistic regression analysis

9. Principal component analysis

10. Factor analysis

11. Canonical correlation analysis

12. Cluster analysis

13. Discriminant analysis
courses.feedback_evaluation:
• The suggestions and information from the early course evaluation

• Students’ reaction during the lectures

• Students’ feedback and suggestion from WebCT forum

• Informal interaction with students and tutors

• Student performance in the class and examination

• Previous course evaluation results
courses.required_readings:
• Marcoulides George A. and Scott L. Hershberger (1997), Chapter 2 Basic Matrix Algebra, Multivariate Statistical Methods: A First Course, Mahwah: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates, 9-22

• Griffith Daniel A. (2003), Spatial Autocorrelation and spatial Filtering: Gaining Understanding Through Theory and Scientific Visualization, Germany: Springer

• Hsieh Chun-Ying, Chou Kuo-Ping (2002), A spatial autocorrelation analysis of aging distribution and transition, Journal of Population Studies, Vol 25, pp, 91-119

• Kachigan Sam Kash (1991) Chapter 4 Regression analysis, Multivariate Statistical Analysis: A Conceptual Introduction, New York: Radius Press, 160-193

• Huang Y, Y Leung and J Shen (2007), Cities and Globalization: An International Cities Perspective, Urban Geography, Vol. 28, No.3, 209-231.

• Loo, Beckyp. Y. (2000), an application of canonical correlation analysis in regional science: the interrelationships between transport and development in China’s Zhujiang Delta, Journal of Regional Science, Vol 40, No. 1,

• Marcoulides George A. and Scott L. Hershberger (1997), Chapter 6 Canonical Correlation, Multivariate Statistical Methods: A First Course, Mahwah: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates, 133-161

• Epperson Bryank, Li Tianquan (1996), Measurement of genetic structure within populations using Moren’s spatial autocorrelation statistics, Population Biology, Vol 93, pp. 10528-10532.

• Anderson T.W. (2003), An Introduction to Multivariate Statistical Analysis, Third Edition, USA: Wiley Interscience

• Wong David W.S. and Jay Lee (2005), Statistical Analysis of Geographic Information with ArcView GIS, New Jersey: John Wiley & Sons, Inc.
courses.recommended_readings:
• Goodchild Michael F. (1986), Spatial Autocorrelation, Norwich: Geo Books, Catmog 47

• Johnson, Richard A. & Dean W. Wichern (2002), Applied Multivariate Statistical Analysis, Prentice-Hall, 5th edition

• Johnston R.J. (1980), Multivariate Statistical Analysis in Geography, London: Longman Group Limited

• Kachigan Sam Kash (1991), Multivariate Statistical Analysis: A Conceptual Introduction,New York: Radius Press

• Marcoulides George A. and Scott L. Hershberger (1997), Multivariate Statistical Methods: A First Course, Mahwah: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Special Topics in Geography of Pacific Asia
courses.description: This course reviews important literature on geographical issues in the Pacific Asia region, evaluating source materials and discussing techniques for research in China/Asia. Topics to be discussed emphasize the impact of physical environment and natural resources on the development of primary, secondary and tertiary activities in Pacific Asia, as well as the location and spatial structure of various social and economic activities.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Geography and Resource Management
courses.learning_outcomes:
Through attending this course, research postgraduate students should be able to:
• Refine research design and methodology
• Sharpen research focus
• Familiarize with existing literature on geographical issues in the Pacific Asia region
• evaluate source materials and discuss techniques for research in China/Asia
• communicate in writing format the research ideas with supervisor(s)
• participate in research seminars and other academic activities for keeping pace with research frontiers
courses.course_syllabus: Each student discusses with his/her supervisor(s) and make individualized research and study plan with specified key milestones for fulfilling graduation requirements step by step.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
* Individual meetings between the supervisor and the student
* Comments and responses through study plans
courses.required_readings: Each student should discuss with his/her supervisor(s) for a unique set of readings, corresponding to his/her own research. The reading list should be kept up to date for enabling the student at the forefront of this/her research field.
courses.recommended_readings: Each student should discuss with his/her supervisor(s) for a unique set of readings, corresponding to his/her own research. The reading list should be kept up to date for enabling the student at the forefront of this/her research field.

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Special Topics in Human Geography
courses.description: This course reviews important literature on human geographical issues. Topics are chosen from the major sub-fields of human geography, such as population, economic, urban and cultural geography and are discussed with emphasis on different methodologies and implications in the understanding of human geographical phenomena.

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Special Topics in Environmental and Resource Management
courses.description: This course examines the interrelations between human activities, natural resources and the environment, as well as the necessity for a sustainable basis for development. Special emphasis will be placed on environmental and resource management options, confl icts, strategies and policy-making. Case studies will be discussed where appropriate.

courses.subject: GRMD
courses.title: Special Topics in Geoinformation Science
courses.description: This course examines the theory and practice of the rapid development in geoinformation science. Topics to be covered include spatial data management using GIS, GIS implementation and design, virtual geographic environment, digital image processing techniques in remote sensing, advance spatial modeling techniques, spatial decision support systems, digital earth and digital cities and social impact of geoinformation science.
